commit_message:
Fix html_last_updated_fmt for Python3

Fix the Sphinx html_last_updated_fmt for Python3. The
html_last_updated_fmt option is interpreted as a byte
string in python3, causing Sphinx build to break.
This patch makes it utf-8 string.

Change-Id: I8d47b0ab690fd682c4e72b742b68b7bf9201557a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-specs refs/changes/24/475224/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: try: html_last_updated_fmt = subprocess.check_output(git_cmd).decode('utf-8') except Exception: warnings.warn('Cannot get last updated time from git repository. ' 'Not setting "html_last_updated_fmt".')

subject: Add limit, offset, order in collection GET
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-02-22 01:08:36.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/fuel-web/commit/909b7dcd3691315ac51ff193671f2f6517b43e8b', 'message': 'Add limit, offset, order in collection GET

Allow limiting the number of objects returned via GET
by providing "limit"
Example: api/notifications?limit=5

Allow offseting (skipping N first records) via "offset"
Example: api/notifications?offset=100

Allow ordering of objects by providing "order_by"
Example: api/notifications?order_by=-id

Add helper functions/classes to:
- get HTTP parameters (limit, offset, order_by)
- get scoped collection query by applying 4 operations
  filter, order, offset, limit
- set Conent-Range header if scope limits are present

Make default NailgunCollection's GET utilize scoped query
This makes default (parent) GET of child handlers support paging
and ordering (overriden GET methods will not get this functionality
automatically)
NailgunCollection.GET is also an example of how to implement
this new functionality.

Helper functions/classes can be utilized in child handler methods
to implement filters / ordering / paging

commit_message:
Add limit, offset, order in collection GET

Allow limiting the number of objects returned via GET
by providing "limit"
Example: api/notifications?limit=5

Allow offseting (skipping N first records) via "offset"
Example: api/notifications?offset=100

Allow ordering of objects by providing "order_by"
Example: api/notifications?order_by=-id

Add helper functions/classes to:
- get HTTP parameters (limit, offset, order_by)
- get scoped collection query by applying 4 operations
  filter, order, offset, limit
- set Conent-Range header if scope limits are present

Make default NailgunCollection's GET utilize scoped query
This makes default (parent) GET of child handlers support paging
and ordering (overriden GET methods will not get this functionality
automatically)
NailgunCollection.GET is also an example of how to implement
this new functionality.

Helper functions/classes can be utilized in child handler methods
to implement filters / ordering / paging

Related-Bug: 1657348
Change-Id: I7760465f70b3f69791e7a0c558a26e8ba55c934a
(cherry picked from commit 03aaca2deeb062e962a81d16c2a75fb5fccfc265)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-web refs/changes/17/436717/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: class _range_not_satisfiable(web.HTTPError): message = 'Requested Range Not Satisfiable' def __init__(self): super(_range_not_satisfiable, self).__init__( status='416 Range Not Satisfiable', data=self.message ) 416: _range_not_satisfiable,class Pagination(object): """Get pagination scope from init or HTTP request arguments""" def convert(self, x): """ret. None if x=None, else ret. x as int>=0; else raise 400""" val = x if val is not None: if type(val) is not int: try: val = int(x) except ValueError: raise BaseHandler.http(400, 'Cannot convert "%s" to int' % x) # raise on negative values if val < 0: raise BaseHandler.http(400, 'Negative limit/offset not \ allowed') return val def get_order_by(self, order_by): if order_by: order_by = [s.strip() for s in order_by.split(',') if s.strip()] return order_by if order_by else None def __init__(self, limit=None, offset=None, order_by=None): if limit is not None or offset is not None or order_by is not None: # init with provided arguments self.limit = self.convert(limit) self.offset = self.convert(offset) self.order_by = self.get_order_by(order_by) else: # init with HTTP arguments self.limit = self.convert(web.input(limit=None).limit) self.offset = self.convert(web.input(offset=None).offset) self.order_by = self.get_order_by(web.input(order_by=None) .order_by) def get_scoped_query_and_range(self, pagination=None, filter_by=None): """Get filtered+paged collection query and collection.ContentRange obj Return a scoped query, and if pagination is requested then also return ContentRange object (see NailgunCollection.content_range) to allow to set Content-Range header (outside of this functon). If pagination is not set/requested, return query to all collection's objects. Allows getting object count without getting objects - via content_range if pagination.limit=0. :param pagination: Pagination object :param filter_by: filter dict passed to query.filter_by(\*\*dict) :type filter_by: dict :returns: SQLAlchemy query and ContentRange object """ pagination = pagination or Pagination() query = None content_range = None if self.collection and self.collection.single.model: query, content_range = self.collection.scope(pagination, filter_by) if content_range: if not content_range.valid: raise self.http(416, 'Requested range "%s" cannot be ' 'satisfied' % content_range) return query, content_range def set_content_range(self, content_range): """Set Content-Range header to indicate partial data :param content_range: NailgunCollection.content_range named tuple """ txt = 'objects {x.first}-{x.last}/{x.total}'.format(x=content_range) web.header('Content-Range', txt) * 400 (Bad Request) * 406 (requested range not satisfiable) query, content_range = self.get_scoped_query_and_range() if content_range: self.set_content_range(content_range) q = self.collection.eager(query, self.eager)

commit_message:
Add 'Container' field for MD parser

The logic of filtering of fake RAID MD heavily relies on the
presence of of 'Container' field inside of parsed data.
If this field is missing, it will never figure out the name of any
fake RAID devices and its component.

This patch adds this field to a parser.

In addition to that, it also logs all found fake RAIDs and
their components for the sake of easy debugging.

Change-Id: I2066c5a0e995e542271cd308c9d83e2373787be4
Closes-Bug: #1617071
(cherry picked from commit 60173537665464db260fb93829eb8affced33535)

commit_message:
Don't override LC_ALL

In Ubuntu (14.04) LC_ALL is not set by default,
other variables are set with UTF-8. Such combi-
nation of settings is valid for working with
non-ASCII characters.
Setting LC_ALL to "C" will override all other
LC_* settings and force ASCII usage. This obstructs
the work with Unicode variables in OSC arguments
(e.g. command 'glance image-create --name 試験画像'
will fail)
As OS works with UTF-8, so we shouldn't hinder.

Change-Id: I9ba428ac4e70cf7d7309054ccb63a46d496a8b4c
Closes-bug: #1543102
(cherry picked from commit 738a804960b8276e85eebd1fd3e37ba8212de122)

commit_message:
Disable docker services when destroy containers.

Services docker-<containername> should be disabled when
there are no containers. That privents from issues
during restart (it's needed for upgrade).
That commit add container auto disable after destroy
and auto enable after start to dockerctl.

Change-Id: Id8778ff539bfc9a7f86ddadded446e0fd730e9a3
Closes-Bug: #1659823

subject: Add more checks to OCF scripts
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-07-19 15:41:30.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/fuel-library/commit/0d7dfc85afe91dbf4cdcae3dbe0e9f157d08acd7', 'message': 'Add more checks to OCF scripts

This commit introduces new health checks in OCF scripts.
ns_haproxy:
        Added checking responsiveness by reading from the stats socket
        which listens by default on the management VIP. This check works
        only on the node which has the management VIP at the moment.
ns_IPAddr2:
        Added a ping check to make sure we have working L3+

commit_message:
Add more checks to OCF scripts

This commit introduces new health checks in OCF scripts.
ns_haproxy:
        Added checking responsiveness by reading from the stats socket
        which listens by default on the management VIP. This check works
        only on the node which has the management VIP at the moment.
        Misc: fix bash comprehension
ns_IPAddr2:
        Added a ping check to make sure we have working L3+
        connectivity.

Although this conditions are extremely rare to occur it would be better
to check resources more deeply.

Co-Authored-By: Alexey Zvyagintsev <azvyagintsev@mirantis.com>

Change-Id: I92b6ab06f13b47740e417c8780254daa07799b77
Closes-Bug: #1704657
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-library refs/changes/53/485253/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: haproxy_get_stats() { # this function checks if this node has the b_management interface # (i.e. the VIP is on this node) then checks if the haproxy process # is reponsive by getting its statistics from the management socket local MGMT_PORT local MGMT_IP local EC MGMT_PORT=10000 MGMT_IP=$(ip netns exec haproxy ip -f inet addr show dev b_management | grep -Po "inet \K[\d.]+") EC=$? if [[ $EC -ne 0 ]]; then # we do not have VIP here so it is ok to return OCF_SUCCESS ocf_log info "haproxy daemon running as slave" return $OCF_SUCCESS fi curl -m 5 -s -o /dev/null http://${MGMT_IP}:${MGMT_PORT}/ EC=$? if [[ $EC -ne 0 ]]; then # our check failed ocf_log err "haproxy does not respond on statistics socket" return $OCF_ERR_GENERIC else ocf_log info "haproxy is running and responsive" return $OCF_SUCCESS fi } haproxy_get_stats return $?

commit_message:
Correct logical expressions for storage backends

After introducing the change Iead5167210c4132badb866afc25d4ef14e27f6b2
swift isn't installed if ceph used as a backend for images
and not for object-storage service. In this sutiation we end up
with absence of object-storage at all which is wrong.

The commit introduces changes which makes possible
to swift been installed if ceph used only for image service.

Change-Id: If319845aa9f2d9b3ca07936350ef374f504679cb
Closes-Bug: #1604879

commit_message:
Misuse of the word Disable instead of Enable

In the section MySQL, the description of enabling the resource
clone_p_mysql uses Disable where it should be Enable.

commit_message:
fixed grub2 config path guessing on rhel7

Currently fuel-agent installs grub2 config in invalid
location for rhel7. Thus provisioned node cannot boot.
This problem can be fixed by re-ordering paths in
guess_grub2_conf() method. Also this change makes
grub version determination more generic.

Closes-Bug: #1627794
Change-Id: Ide299fd7b5045fa6383eb5e12f2b9597431349e8
Signed-off-by: Pavel Glushchak <pglushchak@virtuozzo.com>

deleted_lines: def guess_grub2_conf(chroot=''): for filename in ('/boot/grub/grub.cfg', '/boot/grub2/grub.cfg'): if os.path.isdir(os.path.dirname(chroot + filename)): return filename raise errors.GrubUtilsError('grub2 config file not found') raise errors.GrubUtilsError('grub2 defaul config file not found')def grub2_cfg(kernel_params='', chroot='', grub_timeout=10): cmd = [guess_grub2_mkconfig(chroot), '-o', guess_grub2_conf(chroot)]

commit_message:
Make graph download command more predictable

Now if we try to download graph with any task level parameters
without specifying any filename the result (by default) will be
stored in 'cluster_graph.yaml'.
This patch:
  * makes default filename more accurate based on input parameters
    (environment id, task level graph value and format)
  * adds support to download graph in JSON format

  fuel2 graph download [-h] -e ENV (-a | -c | -p | -r)
                       [-t GRAPH_TYPE][-f FILE]

subject: Replace six.iteritems() with .items()
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-02-06 14:09:16.000000000', 'files': ['fuelclient/cli/actions/plugins.py', 'fuelclient/objects/openstack_config.py', 'fuelclient/v1/base_v1.py', 'fuelclient/v1/plugins.py', 'fuelclient/v1/deployment_history.py', 'fuelclient/tests/utils/fake_plugin.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/python-fuelclient/commit/082e65bfae6dc20501393f08f582b220a0aa1af6', 'message': 'Replace six.iteritems() with .items()

1.As mentioned in [1], we should avoid using
six.iteritems to achieve iterators. We can
use dict.items instead, as it will return
iterators in PY3 as well. And dict.items/keys
will more readable. 2.In py2, the performance
about list should be negligible, see the link [2].
[1] https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Python3
[2] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2015-June/066391.html

Change-Id: Icd8635f99bb76b38668c631be74fdeb70e59e440
'}]
commit_message:
Replace six.iteritems() with .items()

1.As mentioned in [1], we should avoid using
six.iteritems to achieve iterators. We can
use dict.items instead, as it will return
iterators in PY3 as well. And dict.items/keys
will more readable. 2.In py2, the performance
about list should be negligible, see the link [2].
[1] https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Python3
[2] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2015-June/066391.html

Change-Id: Icd8635f99bb76b38668c631be74fdeb70e59e440
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-fuelclient refs/changes/18/429718/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: for k, v in kwargs.items():
deleted_lines: import six for k, v in six.iteritems(kwargs):

commit_message:
Replace assertRaisesRegexp with assertRaisesRegex

This replaces the deprecated (in python 3.2) unittest.TestCase
method assertRaisesRegexp() with assertRaisesRegex().

Change-Id: I15049346fead266312a280b6619fe45deee5f1a0

subject: Remove support for py34.
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-06-08 07:25:46.000000000', 'files': ['setup.cfg'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/python-fuelclient/commit/c91a99d9548f6682c097f2f2d908dcd20bd2932d', 'message': 'Remove support for py34.

The gating on python 3.4 is restricted to <= Mitaka. This is due to
the change from Ubuntu Trusty to Xenial, where only python3.5 is
available. There is no need to continue to keep these settings.

Change-Id: Iab562c5bea2abbb84d34e9f4d1cfcc7b64b845aa
'}]
commit_message:
Remove support for py34.

The gating on python 3.4 is restricted to <= Mitaka. This is due to
the change from Ubuntu Trusty to Xenial, where only python3.5 is
available. There is no need to continue to keep these settings.

Change-Id: Iab562c5bea2abbb84d34e9f4d1cfcc7b64b845aa
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-fuelclient refs/changes/15/472115/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Update process for ussuri-1 weeks

Update process based on what happened in the weeks before and after
ussuri-1.

NB: actions around governance/releases consistency checks will be added
later, when the tool is ready and standing issues are resolved.

Change-Id: I046fd116c8d91bb6707855c9ba489b8d5791b45b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/releases refs/changes/85/699685/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: #. At the end of the week, send the following weekly email content:: Development Focus ----------------- The $SERIES-1 milestone is next week, on $milestone1! Project team plans for the $SERIES cycle should now be solidified. General Information ------------------- If you planned to change the release model for any of your deliverables this cycle, please remember to do so ASAP, before milestone-1. Libraries need to be released at least once per milestone period. Next week, the release team will propose releases for any library which had changes but has not been otherwise released since the $LASTSERIES release. PTL's or release liaisons, please watch for these and give a +1 to acknowledge them. If there is some reason to hold off on a release, let us know that as well, by posting a -1. If we do not hear anything at all by the end of the week, we will assume things are OK to proceed. NB: If one of your libraries is still releasing 0.x versions, start thinking about when it will be appropriate to do a 1.0 version. The version number does signal the state, real or perceived, of the library, so we strongly encourage going to a full major version once things are in a good and usable state. Upcoming Deadlines & Dates -------------------------- $SERIES-1 milestone: $milestone1#. Propose autoreleases for cycle-with-intermediary libraries which did not release since the previous release. - List them using:: tox -e venv -- list-deliverables --unreleased \ --model cycle-with-intermediary --type client-library --type library - Generate release requests for all cycle-with-intermediary libraries which had changes, but did not release since the previous release. That patch will be used as a base to communicate with the team: if a team wants to wait for a specific patch to make it to the library, someone from the team can -1 the patch to have it held, or update that patch with a different commit SHA. - Between Tuesday and Thursday, merge as soon as possible the patches that get +1 from the PTL or the release liaison. - On the Friday, merge patches that did not get any feedback from PTL or release liaison. Discuss standing -1s to see if they should be granted an exception and wait until next week.#. At the end of the week, send the following weekly email content:: Development Focus ----------------- We are now past the $SERIES-1 milestone. Teams should now be focused on feature development and completion of release cycle goals [0]. [0] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/selected/$SERIES/index.html General Information ------------------- Our next milestone in this development cycle will be $SERIES-2, on $milestone2. This milestone is when we freeze the list of deliverables that will be included in the $SERIES final release, so if you plan to introduce new deliverables in this release, please propose a change to add an empty deliverable file in the deliverables/$SERIES directory of the openstack/releases repository. Now is also generally a good time to look at bugfixes that were introduced in the master branch that might make sense to be backported and released in a stable release. If you have any question around the OpenStack release process, feel free to ask on this mailing-list or on the #openstack-release channel on IRC. Upcoming Deadlines & Dates -------------------------- $SERIES-2 Milestone: $milestone2 Week after milestone-1 ====================== #. Review any remaining milestone-1 exceptions
deleted_lines: #. In the weekly email, remind liaisons to ensure that their release model is set properly before the first milestone.#. Generate a list of all cycle-with-intermediary libraries which did not release since the previous release. For this, run:: tox -e venv -- list-deliverables --unreleased \ --model cycle-with-intermediary --type client-library --type library Generate release requests for all cycle-with-intermediary libraries which had changes, but did not release since the previous release. That patch will be used as a base to communicate with the team: if a team wants to wait for a specific patch to make it to the library, someone from the team can -1 the patch to have it held, or update that patch with a different commit SHA.

'fuelclient/objects/network_group.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/python-fuelclient/commit/2b3cb11e881668e07757368d603a5b978ec6fae6', 'message': 'Retire repository

Fuel (from openstack namespace) and fuel-ccp (in x namespace)
repositories are unused and ready to retire.

This change removes all content from the repository and adds the usual
README file to point out that the repository is retired following the
process from
https://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/drivers.html#retiring-a-project

commit_message:
Retire repository

Fuel (from openstack namespace) and fuel-ccp (in x namespace)
repositories are unused and ready to retire.

This change removes all content from the repository and adds the usual
README file to point out that the repository is retired following the
process from
https://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/drivers.html#retiring-a-project

See also
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-December/011647.html

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/699362
Change-Id: I1cdc15fbd41ebea088c76729abf6b120165b9ed1

deleted_lines: # Copyright 2014 Mirantis, Inc. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. from operator import attrgetter from fuelclient.objects.base import BaseObject class NetworkGroup(BaseObject): class_api_path = "networks/" instance_api_path = "networks/{0}/" @property def name(self): return self.get_fresh_data()["name"] @classmethod def create(cls, name, release, vlan, cidr, gateway, group_id, meta=None): metadata = { 'notation': 'cidr', 'render_type': None, 'map_priority': 2, 'configurable': True, 'use_gateway': False, 'name': name, 'cidr': cidr, 'vlan_start': vlan } if meta: metadata.update(meta) network_group = { 'name': name, 'release': release, 'vlan_start': vlan, 'cidr': cidr, 'gateway': gateway, 'meta': metadata, 'group_id': group_id, } data = cls.connection.post_request( cls.class_api_path, network_group, ) return cls.init_with_data(data) def set(self, data): vlan = data.pop('vlan', None) if vlan is not None: data['vlan_start'] = vlan return self.connection.put_request( self.instance_api_path.format(self.id), data) def delete(self): return self.connection.delete_request( self.instance_api_path.format(self.id) ) class NetworkGroupCollection(object): def __init__(self, networks): self.collection = networks @classmethod def init_with_ids(cls, ids): return cls(map(NetworkGroup, ids)) @classmethod def init_with_data(cls, data): return cls(map(NetworkGroup.init_with_data, data)) def __str__(self): return "{0} [{1}]".format( self.__class__.__name__, ", ".join(map(lambda n: str(n.id), self.collection)) ) def __iter__(self): return iter(self.collection) @property def data(self): return map(attrgetter("data"), self.collection) @classmethod def get_all(cls): return cls(NetworkGroup.get_all()) def filter_by_group_id(self, group_id): self.collection = filter(lambda net: net.data['group_id'] == group_id, self.collection)

commit_message:
Add support for custom Elasticsearch config

Elasticsearch Curator will be driven by custom config. This adds
support in Kayobe for managing it.

Change-Id: Ie739ffbd67c6c26175f152449a7b7276ffa87824
Story: 2006852
Task: 37443

commit_message:
tempest: Only enable xvpvnc_console prior to Ussuri

Support for this console type is being removed by the following topic:

https://review.opendev.org/#/q/topic:bp/remove-xvpvncproxy

Change-Id: I0afc70ad9eda425eabf2a1a20e72787b92e0cc31
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/devstack refs/changes/91/698591/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Only enable xvpvnc_console prior to Ussuri where support was removed. if [[ "$TARGET_BRANCH" =~ stable/(ocata|pike|queens|rocky|stein|train) ]]; then iniset $TEMPEST_CONFIG compute-feature-enabled xvpvnc_console True fi

commit_message:
[ceph-client] remove rbd pool init step

This it to remove "rbd"  pool intilization since its not
required as appliction enable in next step does the same.

Change-Id: I07ecdbe417f0156005ebf7cef8fd9e40bace3920
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-helm-infra refs/changes/48/698048/7 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # waiting 30 seconds for cluster to get ready seelp 30 sleep 10 UPDATED_PG_VALUE=$(ceph --cluster "${CLUSTER}" osd pool get "${POOL_NAME}" "${PG_PARAM}" | awk "/^${PG_PARAM}:/ { print \$NF }") cnt=0 until [ "${POOL_PLACEMENT_GROUPS}" == "${UPDATED_PG_VALUE}"] || [ $cnt -ge 6 ]; do sleep 5 ceph --cluster "${CLUSTER}" osd pool set "${POOL_NAME}" "${PG_PARAM}" "${POOL_PLACEMENT_GROUPS}" ((cnt++)) done

commit_message:
Retire fuel and fuel-ccp repositories (step 2)

Retire fuel from openstack namespace and fuel-ccp from x namespace,
these repositories are dead.
This includes the tuning-box repo, it's part of fuel.

Announcement:
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-December/011647.html

Also remove fuel-specs from specs index page.

This is step 2 in
https://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/drivers.html#retiring-a-project

Change-Id: I1fa7d5d38afb91f5bdd8bae0efe0ee8244cf22a8

commit_message:
Fix deploy-ansible-docker-support role

This updates the deploy-ansible-docker-support role to remove the
become and become_user configuration options from the included tasks
and instead adds them at the block level

Change-Id: I77ab70147b9ec604c7f3cb33aef191c8f201d478
Signed-off-by: Steve Wilkerson <sw5822@att.com>

commit_message:
reviewers: make --project and --stable mutually exclusive

When using the reviewers command to get stats on stable branch
reviews, I always think I can specify --stable and --project nova
to get nova stable reviews, but that's not how the command
works and the --project option is ignored resulting in a report
which I don't expect, i.e. there are non-nova reviewers in the
report.

This makes --project and --stable mutually exclusive to avoid that
confusion.

Change-Id: Ie9938f5e68f27b9a5a58635be2185365f041136f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/reviewstats refs/changes/48/692848/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # --stable and --project are mutually exclusive right now, so if # --project is specified it's likely an attempt to only show stable # reviews for a given project which isn't how --stable works right now # unfortunately, so error out to let the user know they are trying to # do something unsupported if both are specified. # It would be a nice feature addition to allow specifying --project with # --stable and filter the stable.json subprojects by the given project. project_group = optparser.add_mutually_exclusive_group(required=False) project_group.add_argument( help='JSON file describing the project to generate stats for. ' 'Mutually exclusive with --stable.') '-a', '--all', action='store_true', project_group.add_argument( 'open stable branches. Mutually exclusive with --project.')
deleted_lines: optparser.add_argument( help='JSON file describing the project to generate stats for') '-a', '--all', action='store_true', default=False, optparser.add_argument( 'open stable branches.')

commit_message:
Switch reviewers command to use argparse

optparse is deprecated in python 2.7 and not available
starting in python3. This changes the reviewers command
to use argparse instead.

Change-Id: I76f270b4e998e8cf2a56c12d7bf70c0651c69d16

[{'number': 1, 'created': '2019-12-17 19:19:37.000000000', 'files': ['docker/monasca/monasca-grafana/Dockerfile.j2'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/kolla/commit/b2e2c68b86b7a7b16ea270f53dde7e400cae1560', 'message': 'Fix monasca-grafana being unbuildable due to old npm

commit_message:
Fix monasca-grafana being unbuildable due to old npm

Affected builds on Ubuntu which had:
npm 3.5.2
while the latest was:
npm 6.13.4
And CentOS had:
npm 5.6.0

This patch runs npm update via npm.
Pinned to 6.x.

Additionally, this moves npm packages prefix (root) to
/usr/local to avoid conflicts with native packages.

Change-Id: Ibaacc1cc478b2b2f8196a5da4eea3570d7d310ff
Closes-bug: #1856699
(cherry picked from commit 308e85aa413da84ed107b27fa09a3f0e0a64392f)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla refs/changes/82/699482/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # NOTE(yoctozepto): Update npm to 6.x version to avoid issues with metadata parsing. # NPM installs itself in /usr/local/bin (the default in Ubuntu) which is not in the PATH. # This is forced for all distros to avoid conflicts with native packages. && npm config set prefix /usr/local -g \ && npm install npm@6.x -g \ && /usr/local/bin/npm install \

commit_message:
Tune down multinode concurrency

Reduce the multinode concurrency and number
of VMs so we don't run Rackspace VMs out of
disk space.

This is an issue that was reported by the
infra team.

[0]: http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/irclogs/%23openstack-ironic/%23openstack-ironic.2019-12-16.log.html#t2019-12-16T17:38:15

Change-Id: I867bac9e247605e561cc7ee4522f70ce6de368d4

Support L3 agent cleanup on shutdown

Add an option to delete all routers on agent shutdown.

Closes-Bug: #1851609
Change-Id: I7a4056680d8453b2ef2dcc853437a0ec4b3e8044

commit_message:
Invoke correct python version in shell scripts

The oslotest shell scripts were using /usr/bin/python by default, and did
take into account the $PYTHON variable, so one could choose to use
Python 3 instead of Python 2.

This patch looks if a $PYTHON variable exists. If not, then it sets it
to "python" by default, otherwise, it uses whatever exists, so it is now
possible to do PYTHON=python3 oslo_debug_helper for starting tests.

Change-Id: I6df0ac0d84fd964251a1af9e27dadb954a2ad691
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslotest refs/changes/62/571962/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if [ -n "${PYTHON}" ] ; then PYTHON=python fi our_name=$(${PYTHON} setup.py --name)rm -rf $(${PYTHON} setup.py --name).egg-info ${PYTHON} setup.py egg_info .tox/$venv/bin/${PYTHON} /usr/local/jenkins/slave_scripts/subunit2html.py ./subunit_log.txt testr_results.html export PYTHON=.tox/$venv/bin/${PYTHON}
deleted_lines: our_name=$(python setup.py --name)rm -rf $(python setup.py --name).egg-info python setup.py egg_info .tox/$venv/bin/python /usr/local/jenkins/slave_scripts/subunit2html.py ./subunit_log.txt testr_results.html export PYTHON=.tox/$venv/bin/python

commit_message:
Remove the neutron-grenade job definition

All the user of neutron-grenade from Ussuri gate
onwards has been switched to grenade-py3 job (except
neutron which is running neutron-grenade-multinode).

We can remove the job definition also now and all
stable gate using this job will find the job definition
from neutron stable branches.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/694234/
Change-Id: I631f0bfbe7e4ee2df89e2eca2060331796e7a0b2

commit_message:
Block ability update callback_url

A malicious user with:

* API access normally reserved for the provisioning,
  cleaning, rescue networks.
* Insight about a node, such as a MAC address, or baremetal node
  UUID.
* Insight into the state of the node, such as the access provided
  to Compute API users, or other Bare Metal API users.

Can submit an erroneous ``heartbeat`` to the ironic-api endpoint
with a ``callback_url`` that is not of the actual intended agent.
This can potentially cause a rescue, cleaning, or deployment
operation to be derailed, or at worst commands to be sent to
to an endpoint the malicious user controls.

Story: 2006773
Task: 37295
Change-Id: I1a5e3c2b34d45c06fb74e82d0f30735ce9041914
(cherry picked from commit 931c12598296dad676b2d64b66fef6e95ad3939b)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic refs/changes/05/699305/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: --- security: - | Prevents additional updates of an agent ``callback_url`` through the agent heartbeat ``/v1/heartbeat/<node_uuid>`` endpoint as the ``callback_url`` should remain stable through the cleaning, provisioning, or rescue processes. Should anything such as an unexpected agent reboot cause the ``callback_url``, heartbeat operations will now be ignored. More information can be found at `story 2006773 <https://storyboard.openstack.org/#!/story/2006773>`_.

commit_message:
Update nodejs and npm packages

This updated allow to use python3 to build grafana

Update nodejs from 8.10.0 to 10.17.0
Update npm from 3.5.4 to 6.11.3

Change-Id: I709d1e6134150f1648a8f409ce438544e15ce403

deleted_lines: # Is required to use python2.7 to build grafana because node-gyp support only python2 npm config set python /usr/bin/python2.7

commit_message:
pbr show-next-version command

Allow to display the next release version, as
calculated using sem-ver footers in commit messages.

Also available:
    python setup.py show_release_version

Change-Id: I4ba355225c7f22f1923acb7fd844deb61a1720ea
sem-ver: feature
Signed-off-by: Gaetan Semet <gaetan@xeberon.net>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/pbr refs/changes/31/561731/9 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import re import shutil import subprocessif sys.version_info[0] == 3: from shlex import quote else: from pipes import quote def git_tag(args): if not args.quiet: print("Tagging package {}".format(args.name)) info = _get_info(args.name) version = info['version'] re_version = re.compile(r'(\d+\.\d+\.\d+(\.0?([a-c]|rc)[0-9]+){0,1})(|\.dev.*)') g = re_version.match(version) if not g: if not args.quiet: print("ERROR: invalid version: {!r}".format(version)) return 1 tag_version = g.group(1) if not args.quiet: print("Tagging with version: ", version) tag_cmd = ["git", "tag", tag_version] if args.message: tag_cmd.extend(["-m", args.message.format(version=tag_version)]) if args.sign: tag_cmd.append("-s") s_tag_cmd = " ".join([quote(c) for c in tag_cmd]) if args.execute: if not args.quiet: print("Executing git: {}".format(s_tag_cmd)) o = subprocess.check_output(tag_cmd) print(o) else: if not args.quiet: print("git command to create the tag:") print(s_tag_cmd) cmd_git_tag = subparsers.add_parser('git-tag', help=' Tag git with the new version') cmd_git_tag.add_argument("-v", "--v-version", dest="v_version", action="store_true", help="create a tag v<version>") cmd_git_tag.add_argument("-s", "--sign", dest="sign", action="store_true", help="Sign the tag") cmd_git_tag.add_argument("-q", "--quiet", dest="quiet", action="store_true", help="Keep log to minium") cmd_git_tag.add_argument("-e", "--execute", dest="execute", action="store_true", help=("By default, pbr does not apply the tag, but simply display " "the git command to execute. With -e, really execute git")) cmd_git_tag.add_argument("-m", "--message", dest="message", help=("override default message. " "Use {version} for the version string"), default="Release {version}") cmd_git_tag.set_defaults(func=git_tag) cmd_git_tag.add_argument('name', help='package name to tag')

commit_message:
Update sphinx networkx requirements to match g-r

global-requirements excludes sphinx 1.6.7 and caps python 2 since
sphinx 2.0 no longer supports 2.7.

global-requirements caps python 2 since networkx 2.3 no longer supports 2.7.

Change-Id: Ic7f55ea7be42299cabfc4508e7ce36b23312e00d

commit_message:
Don't run bandit during the pep8 tox run

There is already a tox section for bandit which can be executed via
"tox -ebandit". The command in the pep8 section is just a
duplication.

Change-Id: I259a0a4c4dfafb994033e1b15fcfc4022951bf95

commit_message:
Fix monasca-grafana being unbuildable due to old npm

Affected builds on Ubuntu which had:
npm 3.5.2
while the latest was:
npm 6.13.4
And CentOS had:
npm 5.6.0

This patch runs npm update via npm.
Pinned to 6.x.

Additionally, this moves npm packages prefix (root) to
/usr/local to avoid conflicts with native packages.

Change-Id: Ibaacc1cc478b2b2f8196a5da4eea3570d7d310ff
Closes-bug: #1856699
(cherry picked from commit 308e85aa413da84ed107b27fa09a3f0e0a64392f)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla refs/changes/83/699483/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # NOTE(yoctozepto): Update npm to 6.x version to avoid issues with metadata parsing. # NPM installs itself in /usr/local/bin (the default in Ubuntu) which is not in the PATH. # This is forced for all distros to avoid conflicts with native packages. && npm config set prefix /usr/local -g \ && npm install npm@6.x -g \ && /usr/local/bin/npm install \

commit_message:
Add missing PIP requirements PyMySQL and SQLAlchemy

SQLAlchemy and PyMySQL are missing in requirements.txt/lower-constraints.txt
when osprofiler is isolated from other OpenStack components for instance
installed in Python virtual or in separated container.

Change-Id: I6a8e31177e5adf0a54c2a3ed0b0de18ad0f2ded9
Closes-Bug: #1826646

commit_message:
WIP: Add in-memory key_manager.

The VanillaKeyManager is a in-memory key_manager for development
and testing purposes only. It eliminates the requirement of an
external party such as OpenStack Barbican or HashiCorp Vault
in order to test the KeyManager API.

Change-Id: Ie296b1b195b142ebf9870b1e1ae6a3efc107a8e4
Signed-off-by: Moisés Guimarães de Medeiros <moguimar@redhat.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/castellan refs/changes/45/626945/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. """ Key manager implementation for Vault """ import binascii from cryptography.hazmat.backends import default_backend from cryptography.hazmat.primitives.asymmetric import rsa from cryptography.hazmat.primitives.serialization import Encoding from cryptography.hazmat.primitives.serialization import NoEncryption from cryptography.hazmat.primitives.serialization import PrivateFormat from cryptography.hazmat.primitives.serialization import PublicFormat import os import time import uuid from oslo_log import log as logging from castellan.common import exception from castellan.common.objects import opaque_data as op_data from castellan.common.objects import passphrase from castellan.common.objects import private_key as pri_key from castellan.common.objects import public_key as pub_key from castellan.common.objects import symmetric_key as sym_key from castellan.common.objects import x_509 from castellan.i18n import _ from castellan.key_manager import key_manager LOG = logging.getLogger(__name__) class VanillaKeyManager(key_manager.KeyManager): """Key Manager Interface for an in-memory key manager.""" _secret_type_dict = { op_data.OpaqueData: 'opaque', passphrase.Passphrase: 'passphrase', pri_key.PrivateKey: 'private', pub_key.PublicKey: 'public', sym_key.SymmetricKey: 'symmetric', x_509.X509: 'certificate'} def __init__(self, configuration): self._conf = configuration self._data = {} def create_key_pair(self, context, algorithm, length, expiration=None, name=None): """Creates an asymmetric key pair.""" # Confirm context is provided, if not raise forbidden if not context: msg = _("User is not authorized to use key manager.") raise exception.Forbidden(msg) if algorithm.lower() != 'rsa': raise NotImplementedError( "VaultKeyManager only implements rsa keys" ) priv_key = rsa.generate_private_key( public_exponent=65537, key_size=length, backend=default_backend() ) private_key = pri_key.PrivateKey( 'RSA', length, priv_key.private_bytes( Encoding.PEM, PrivateFormat.PKCS8, NoEncryption() ) ) private_key_id = uuid.uuid4().hex private_id = self._store_key_value( private_key_id, private_key ) # pub_key = priv_key.public_key() public_key = pub_key.PublicKey( 'RSA', length, priv_key.public_key().public_bytes( Encoding.PEM, PublicFormat.SubjectPublicKeyInfo ) ) public_key_id = uuid.uuid4().hex public_id = self._store_key_value( public_key_id, public_key ) return private_id, public_id def _store_key_value(self, key_id, value): type_value = self._secret_type_dict.get(type(value)) if type_value is None: raise exception.KeyManagerError( "Unknown type for value : %r" % value) record = { 'type': type_value, 'value': binascii.hexlify(value.get_encoded()).decode('utf-8'), 'algorithm': (value.algorithm if hasattr(value, 'algorithm') else None), 'bit_length': (value.bit_length if hasattr(value, 'bit_length') else None), 'name': value.name, 'created': value.created } self._data[key_id] = record return key_id def create_key(self, context, algorithm, length, name=None, **kwargs): """Creates a symmetric key.""" # Confirm context is provided, if not raise forbidden if not context: msg = _("User is not authorized to use key manager.") raise exception.Forbidden(msg) key_id = uuid.uuid4().hex key_value = os.urandom(length or 32) key = sym_key.SymmetricKey(algorithm, length or 32, key_value, key_id, name or int(time.time())) return self._store_key_value(key_id, key) def store(self, context, key_value, **kwargs): """Stores (i.e., registers) a key with the key manager.""" # Confirm context is provided, if not raise forbidden if not context: msg = _("User is not authorized to use key manager.") raise exception.Forbidden(msg) key_id = uuid.uuid4().hex return self._store_key_value(key_id, key_value) def get(self, context, key_id, metadata_only=False): """Retrieves the key identified by the specified id.""" # Confirm context is provided, if not raise forbidden if not context: msg = _("User is not authorized to use key manager.") raise exception.Forbidden(msg) if not key_id: raise exception.KeyManagerError('key identifier not provided') try: record = self._data[key_id] except KeyError: raise exception.ManagedObjectNotFoundError(uuid=key_id) key = None if metadata_only else binascii.unhexlify(record['value']) clazz = None for type_clazz, type_name in self._secret_type_dict.items(): if type_name == record['type']: clazz = type_clazz if clazz is None: raise exception.KeyManagerError( "Unknown type : %r" % record['type']) if hasattr(clazz, 'algorithm') and hasattr(clazz, 'bit_length'): return clazz(record['algorithm'], record['bit_length'], key, record['name'], record['created'], key_id) else: return clazz(key, record['name'], record['created'], key_id) def delete(self, context, key_id): """Represents deleting the key.""" # Confirm context is provided, if not raise forbidden if not context: msg = _("User is not authorized to use key manager.") raise exception.Forbidden(msg) if not key_id: raise exception.KeyManagerError('key identifier not provided') try: del self._data[key_id] except KeyError: raise exception.ManagedObjectNotFoundError(uuid=key_id) def list(self, context, object_type=None, metadata_only=False): """Lists the managed objects given the criteria.""" # Confirm context is provided, if not raise forbidden if not context: msg = _("User is not authorized to use key manager.") raise exception.Forbidden(msg) if object_type and object_type not in self._secret_type_dict: msg = _("Invalid secret type: %s") % object_type raise exception.KeyManagerError(reason=msg) keys = self._data.keys() objects = [] for obj_id in keys: try: obj = self.get(context, obj_id, metadata_only=metadata_only) if object_type is None or isinstance(obj, object_type): objects.append(obj) except exception.ManagedObjectNotFoundError as e: LOG.warning(_("Error occurred while retrieving object " "metadata, not adding it to the list: %s"), e) pass return objects

commit_message:
cmd: 'pbr boostrap' create setup.[cfg,py] automatically

PBR-adicted developpers could install pbr user-wide with:

  pip install --user pbr

From then, one would be able to create a setup.py and
setup.cfg with:

  pbr bootstrap

sem-ver: feature

Change-Id: I0a3ff3ad0220a10ac507c8f555651e4fee114c8c
Signed-off-by: Gaetan Semet <gaetan@xeberon.net>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/pbr refs/changes/84/559484/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from textwrap import dedentimport sysdef bootstrap(args): with open("setup.py", "w") as f: f.write(dedent( """ #!/usr/bin/env python from setuptools import setup setup(setup_requires=['pbr'], pbr=True) """ ).lstrip()) print("setup.py generated") with open("setup.cfg", "w") as fcfg: fcfg.write(dedent( """ [metadata] name = {package_name} author = {author} author-email = {email} summary = {summary} description-file = README.rst description-content-type = text/x-rst; charset=UTF-8 home-page = {homepage_url} project_urls = Bug Tracker = {bugtracker_url} Documentation = {documentation_url} Source Code = {sourcecode_url} license = {license} classifier = Intended Audience :: Developers Intended Audience :: Information Technology Operating System :: OS Independent Programming Language :: Python keywords = {package_keywork} [files] packages = {package_name} [entry_points] console_scripts = {console_app} = {package_name}.cmd:main """ ).lstrip()) print("setup.cfg generated") cmd_bootstrap = subparsers.add_parser( 'bootstrap', help='Create a setup.py and setup.cfg') cmd_bootstrap.set_defaults(func=bootstrap)

commit_message:
WIP: mock: Fixes missing _autospec key issue

This issue can be encountered when mock.patch is used with
additional kwargs. mock.configure_mock is called before its
_autospec is set.

Change-Id: I388b942b0eb99673adeb5a9073ac2e8f7eb0588f

commit_message:
WIP: mock: Makes _AutospecMagicMock a subclass of _AutospecMock

In the mock module, MagicMock is a subclass of Mock, and the autospec
classes should reflect that.

This is needed for a few tests which checks if an object is an instance
of mock.Mock (_AutospecMock if the mock fixture is used), which would
fail if it is a mock.MagicMock instead (_AutospecMagicMock).

Change-Id: I20f4fb465a81ab64c5b26434ba1a3fa63bfd97d8

commit_message:
Calculate timestamps within DB

Calculating the timestamp in the clients can lead to problems
because network latency is variable, clients experience slightly
different clock drift.

The SQLAlchemy allows us to do this by passing func.now() which
tells the DB to calculate the timestamp itself.

So, in order to make the updated_at and created_at more accurate,
we should calculate the timestamp in db.

Closes-bug: #1787345

Change-Id: I848035e8e8fe53698cafe1571889d74ec65b64f1
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo.db refs/changes/04/592304/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

deleted_lines: created_at = Column(DateTime, default=lambda: timeutils.utcnow()) updated_at = Column(DateTime, onupdate=lambda: timeutils.utcnow())

commit_message:
Add last finished strategy + fast forward

The existing 'aligned_last_finished' was potentially
over-running earlier by aligning
to the nearest time even if the difference between the
last finish time and the next time was less than
the expected spacing. In order to fix this when this
situation happens we need to shift forward to the
next multiple and use that instead.

So this adds a new strategy that does just that.

Change-Id: Idc065484fe58a2ac419a83fc73228d9305ef15f7
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/futurist refs/changes/90/546490/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: next_up = finished_at - math.fmod(finished_at, how_often) next_up += how_often if (next_up - finished_at) < how_often: # Shift it forward to the next boundary so that we don't run earlier # than we really want to; for example, let's assume that it finished # at 1.0 and it is scheduled to run every 3.0 seconds, well we don't # want to run it in 2.0 seconds, but we want to run it instead at # the next aligned offset, which in this case would be 3.0 * 2.0 # or 6.0 finished_at = ((finished_at / how_often) + 1) * how_often next_up = finished_at - math.fmod(finished_at, how_often) next_up += how_often return next_up
deleted_lines: aligned_finished_at = finished_at - math.fmod(finished_at, how_often) return aligned_finished_at + how_often

commit_message:
Use spice_agent_enabled key from cloud-compute relation

spice_agent_enabled is provided by nova-cloud-controller to inform
nova-compute the value that needs to be set in the configuration option
[spice].agent_enabled

Change-Id: I49d6e04a545d4b13f9a65e5fd239aa911e75a3ba
Closes-Bug: #1856602

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2019-08-22 20:07:48.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/95660afdbb1a7019d73375271b38046985c84de1', 'message': "WIP: Fail compute service delete if resource provider delete fails

Change I7b8622b178d5043ed1556d7bdceaf60f47e5ac80 started deleting
the associated resource provider when a compute service is deleted.
However, the delete_resource_provider cascade=True logic only looks
for instances on the given compute service host being deleted which
will miss (1) allocations remaining from evacuated servers and
(2) unconfirmed migrations.

Attempting to delete the resource provider results in an
ResourceProviderInUse error which delete_resource_provider ignores
for legacy reasons. This results in the compute service being
deleted but the resource provider being orphaned. What's more,
attempting to restart the now-deleted compute service will fail
because nova-compute will try to create a new resource provider
with a new uuid but with the same name (based on the hypervisor
hostname).

This change makes SchedulerReportClient.delete_resource_provider
no longer hide the ResourceProviderInUse/ResourceProviderDeletionFailed
errors and let's them raise up to the caller.

There are two callers of this method, one in the API to delete a compute
service and one in the compute manager to cleanup orphan compute nodes
that are in the DB but no longer reported by the driver (which is mostly
an ironic thing). Both call sites are handled.

In the API, we will return a 409 on ResourceProviderInUse giving the user
some information on things to look for and cleanup before retrying the
delete operation. The related functional test for that is also updated
to show it working. A TODO is left in delete_resource_provider for trying
to detect the evacuate scenario and automatically cleaning up and retrying
the delete. That will be addressed in a later change.

The other call in the ComputeManager is handled but just logged for now.
TBD on what we want to do there once this has had wider review.

Change-Id: Ic634a5957e38beca693304c605d1b6fd36eacc77
Partial-Bug: #1829479
Partial-Bug: #1817833

commit_message:
WIP: Fail compute service delete if resource provider delete fails

Change I7b8622b178d5043ed1556d7bdceaf60f47e5ac80 started deleting
the associated resource provider when a compute service is deleted.
However, the delete_resource_provider cascade=True logic only looks
for instances on the given compute service host being deleted which
will miss (1) allocations remaining from evacuated servers and
(2) unconfirmed migrations.

Attempting to delete the resource provider results in an
ResourceProviderInUse error which delete_resource_provider ignores
for legacy reasons. This results in the compute service being
deleted but the resource provider being orphaned. What's more,
attempting to restart the now-deleted compute service will fail
because nova-compute will try to create a new resource provider
with a new uuid but with the same name (based on the hypervisor
hostname).

This change makes SchedulerReportClient.delete_resource_provider
no longer hide the ResourceProviderInUse/ResourceProviderDeletionFailed
errors and let's them raise up to the caller.

There are two callers of this method, one in the API to delete a compute
service and one in the compute manager to cleanup orphan compute nodes
that are in the DB but no longer reported by the driver (which is mostly
an ironic thing). Both call sites are handled.

In the API, we will return a 409 on ResourceProviderInUse giving the user
some information on things to look for and cleanup before retrying the
delete operation. The related functional test for that is also updated
to show it working. A TODO is left in delete_resource_provider for trying
to detect the evacuate scenario and automatically cleaning up and retrying
the delete. That will be addressed in a later change.

The other call in the ComputeManager is handled but just logged for now.
TBD on what we want to do there once this has had wider review.

TODO: likely also want a release note for the API 409 behavior change

Change-Id: Ic634a5957e38beca693304c605d1b6fd36eacc77
Partial-Bug: #1829479
Partial-Bug: #1817833
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/00/678100/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: try: # TODO(mriedem): If this is ironic doing a re-balance # should we really be doing cascading deletes of the # allocations on the node? This was added back when the # ResourceTracker would heal allocations in the # update_available_resource task, but that was removed # in Stein, so if the node was re-balanced to another host # wouldn't this be erroneously dropping the allocations # and you'd have to run heal_allocations to get them back? self.reportclient.delete_resource_provider(context, cn, cascade=True) except (exception.ResourceProviderInUse, exception.ResourceProviderDeletionFailed): # TODO(mriedem): What should we do with this? Just log an # error and hope that on the next pass it will work? # Actually on the next pass we wouldn't even get here # because we deleted the compute node above? So should we # do this before deleting the compute node, like in the # DELETE /os-services/{service_id} API? And/or make this # conditional on the startup value and fail to start if # we can't cleanup the provider? LOG.exception('Failed to delete resource provider for ' 'compute node %s with uuid %s.', cn.hypervisor_hostname, cn.uuid)

commit_message:
Minimal changes to maintain CI with Neutron master

- Hide (by renaming) test files that import Neutron code that now
requires Python 3.  We cannot run those test files anymore, until
we (a) figure out how to run them with an older Neutron version,
or (b) fix the networking-calico as a whole to run under Python 3.

- Remove declarations that we support Python 3, as this is actually
not the case.

- Also remove pypy tox environment, as I don't believe we've ever had
any value from it, and other networking-* projects don't have it.

Change-Id: Ib9c5dec59eb5bffad5ce5d9d13be07e513048871

commit_message:
Add autoprogram_cliff_app_dist_name config opt

This allows consumers to let cliff know who they are, so the
autoprogram-sphinx directive doesn't produce messages like

 This command is provided by the $me plugin.

Change-Id: I2d5a527910ddc64f83d0cba39c584b8b05a299b7

commit_message:
Ceph plugin updates for Luminous

Since the Luminous release of Ceph, the plugin no longer exports metrics
such as object storage daemon stats, placement groups and pool stats.
Check for the installed version of the Ceph command and parse results
according to version.

Include test data for Jewel and Luminous Ceph clusters.

Story: 2005032
Task: 29515

Change-Id: I0aef0db25f49545c715b07880edd57135e3beafe
Co-Authored-By: Bharat Kunwar <bharat@stackhpc.com>
Co-Authored-By: Doug Szumski <doug@stackhpc.com>

subject: Delete resource providers for all nodes when deleting compute service
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2019-06-21 15:27:11.000000000', 'files': ['nova/tests/unit/api/openstack/compute/test_services.py', 'releasenotes/notes/bug-1811726-multi-node-delete-2ba17f02c6171fbb.yaml', 'nova/api/openstack/compute/services.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/bd2e0972993ffd732cde0a3a6154424e74d44f0a', 'message': "Delete resource providers for all nodes when deleting compute service

Change I7b8622b178d5043ed1556d7bdceaf60f47e5ac80 started deleting the
compute node resource provider associated with a compute node when
deleting a nova-compute service. However, it would only delete the
first compute node associated with the service which means for an
ironic compute service that is managing multiple nodes, the resource
providers were not cleaned up in placement. This fixes the issue by
iterating all the compute nodes and cleaning up their providers.
Note this could be potentially a lot of nodes, but we don't really
have many good options here but to iterate them and clean them up
one at a time.

Note that this is best-effort but because of how the
SchedulerReportClient.delete_resource_provider method ignores
ResourceProviderInUse errors, and we could have stale allocations
on the host for which delete_resource_provider is not accounting,
namely allocations from evacuated instances (or incomplete migrations
though you can't migrate baremetal instances today), we could still
delete the compute service and orphan those in-use providers. That,
however, is no worse than before this change where we did not try
to cleanup all providers. The issue described above is being tracked
with bug 1829479 and will be dealt with separately.

Change-Id: I9e852e25ea89f32bf19cdaeb1f5dac8f749f5dbc
Closes-Bug: #1811726
(cherry picked from commit 650fe118d128f09f78552b82abc114bb4b84930e)
(cherry picked from commit e9889be94ee58a6da78ef96d09d8f5282b86f648)
(cherry picked from commit 64d52788831f0e676f0b9bf9780eeadb38232def)
(cherry picked from commit b2f438bab4a0fdaa37b1a57cff0b27fb2a3f3437)
"}]
commit_message:
Delete resource providers for all nodes when deleting compute service

Change I7b8622b178d5043ed1556d7bdceaf60f47e5ac80 started deleting the
compute node resource provider associated with a compute node when
deleting a nova-compute service. However, it would only delete the
first compute node associated with the service which means for an
ironic compute service that is managing multiple nodes, the resource
providers were not cleaned up in placement. This fixes the issue by
iterating all the compute nodes and cleaning up their providers.
Note this could be potentially a lot of nodes, but we don't really
have many good options here but to iterate them and clean them up
one at a time.

Note that this is best-effort but because of how the
SchedulerReportClient.delete_resource_provider method ignores
ResourceProviderInUse errors, and we could have stale allocations
on the host for which delete_resource_provider is not accounting,
namely allocations from evacuated instances (or incomplete migrations
though you can't migrate baremetal instances today), we could still
delete the compute service and orphan those in-use providers. That,
however, is no worse than before this change where we did not try
to cleanup all providers. The issue described above is being tracked
with bug 1829479 and will be dealt with separately.

Change-Id: I9e852e25ea89f32bf19cdaeb1f5dac8f749f5dbc
Closes-Bug: #1811726
(cherry picked from commit 650fe118d128f09f78552b82abc114bb4b84930e)
(cherry picked from commit e9889be94ee58a6da78ef96d09d8f5282b86f648)
(cherry picked from commit 64d52788831f0e676f0b9bf9780eeadb38232def)
(cherry picked from commit b2f438bab4a0fdaa37b1a57cff0b27fb2a3f3437)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/65/666865/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # placement for the compute nodes managed by this service; # remember that an ironic compute service can manage multiple # nodes compute_nodes = objects.ComputeNodeList.get_all_by_host( context, service.host) for compute_node in compute_nodes: self.placementclient.delete_resource_provider( context, compute_node, cascade=True)
deleted_lines: # placement for this compute node self.placementclient.delete_resource_provider( context, service.compute_node, cascade=True)

commit_message:
Remove py2 testing, jobs

Change tox.ini so that all jobs are python3, and add explicit
unit/functional testenvs for the two ussuri python runtimes
(3.6 and 3.7).

Remove py2 jobs from .zuul.yaml and redefine the periodic "tips"
jobs so that they are testing with the ussuri python runtimes.
Added nodeset: ubuntu-bionic to the abstract base jobs so that
py3.7 is available.

Co-authored-by: Ghanshyam Mann <gmann@ghanshyammann.com>
Co-authored-by: Brian Rosmaita <rosmaita.fossdev@gmail.com>

Closes-bug: #1853693
Change-Id: I15467c34fc8466fa1724c5401dc879ae77c1922d

commit_message:
Exclude build request marker from server listing

When listing "real" (already in cell) instances e.g. from
nova_cell1.instances table, a marker option means "start after the
instance with marker".

For VMs:

| uuid | name |
| 1    | vm1  |
| 2    | vm2  |

"openstack server list --marker 1" returns vm2 only.

But for VMs from nova_api.build_requests table it's different.

For VMs:

| uuid | name |
| 1    | vm1  |
| 2    | vm2  |

"openstack server list --marker 1" returns both vm1 and vm2.

This patch excludes instance with marker from listing for
instances from build_requests table.

Closes-Bug: #1808286
Change-Id: I5165b69f956fbf1904112a742698b2739f747e72
(cherry picked from commit 2ef704cba619a149336692311c2614742aa32909)
(cherry picked from commit 3eb0ba988f4cfca4399c92cd6bb7b4ae8665720c)
(cherry picked from commit 8aadd4ebdfea3f1b46b2e2e62b355e8b40b6261b)
(cherry picked from commit 3d3a263789c5cc49899d63d18f9233c981f5b894)

commit_message:
Fix pep8 errors found by hacking 2.0.0

Fix the following issues that are now exposed by hacking version 2.0.0

./networking_ovn/tests/unit/common/test_hash_ring_manager.py:92:38:
F602 dictionary key variable another_host_node repeated with different
values
 hash_dict_after_rebalance = {another_host_node: 'fake-uuid',

Also fixing

./networking_ovn/ovsdb/ovsdb_monitor.py:359:13: F841 local variable
'e' is assigned to but never used

But that is already fixed in the neutron repo, so this is only an
issue in networking-ovn repo.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/699083/

commit_message:
Add traps for py3 and fix remote src

This change adds traps for the FileNotFound exception which is used instead
of OSError when a file is not found. This will ensure that that fall back
exception handeling works properly in py2 and py3.

The remote_src flag was not being respected with the new fallback options,
this change adds a check for remote_src so it works in normal and fallback
mode.

Change-Id: I136dd1f3220d3b004d5275a9fa15edea53d58f6b
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kecarter@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Properly set loopback_users via rabbitmq::loopback_users

Sorta resurrecting https://review.opendev.org/#/c/324016/ now that
https://github.com/voxpupuli/puppet-rabbitmq/pull/699 merged.

This commit prevents a duplicate entry for loopback_users in the
rabbitmq.config file:

{loopback_users, [<<"guest">>]},
{loopback_users, []},

keeping only the expected empty array.

Note: not a 100% clean cherry pick due to tht path changes.

(cherry picked from commit 04a5937e1f1482dd3115ddc809c555abea87e69d)

Change-Id: I0c291bf5611f02983c430179206556bae3b38736
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates refs/changes/55/698655/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: rabbitmq::loopback_users: []

commit_message:
Ignore devices with OSError

This bug handles OSError when trying to read from CDrom devices with no
disc in the is_pristine_disk function which makes the run-action
list-disks to fail.

Change-Id: I5e86895d1adff3f95c7feb5ed0f78b998c28ed1f

added_lines: # The following variable allow switching between Java and Python for # the implementations of the Monasca Persister. If this variable is not set, # then the default is to install the Python implementation of # the Monasca Persister. # Uncomment of the following two lines to choose Java or Python for # the Monasca Pesister. # MONASCA_PERSISTER_IMPLEMENTATION_LANG=${MONASCA_PERSISTER_IMPLEMENTATION_LANG:-java} MONASCA_PERSISTER_IMPLEMENTATION_LANG=${MONASCA_PERSISTER_IMPLEMENTATION_LANG:-python} # Uncomment one of the following two lines to choose either InfluxDB or # Apache Cassandra. # default "influxdb" is selected as metric DB.# MONASCA_METRICS_DB=${MONASCA_METRICS_DB:-cassandra}If you also want the Tempest tests to be installed then add `tempest` and `monasca-tempest-plugin`.enable_plugin monasca-tempest-plugin https://opendev.org/openstack/monasca-tempest-plugin(c) Copyright 2015-2016 Hewlett Packard Enterprise Development Company LP
deleted_lines: SERVICE_TOKEN=111222333444# The following two variables allow switching between Java and Python for the implementations # of the Monasca API and the Monasca Persister. If these variables are not set, then the # default is to install the Python implementations of both the Monasca API and the Monasca Persister. # Uncomment one of the following two lines to choose Java or Python for the Monasca API. MONASCA_API_IMPLEMENTATION_LANG=${MONASCA_API_IMPLEMENTATION_LANG:-java} # MONASCA_API_IMPLEMENTATION_LANG=${MONASCA_API_IMPLEMENTATION_LANG:-python} # Uncomment of the following two lines to choose Java or Python for the Monasca Pesister. MONASCA_PERSISTER_IMPLEMENTATION_LANG=${MONASCA_PERSISTER_IMPLEMENTATION_LANG:-java} # MONASCA_PERSISTER_IMPLEMENTATION_LANG=${MONASCA_PERSISTER_IMPLEMENTATION_LANG:-python} # Uncomment one of the following two lines to choose either InfluxDB or Vertica. # default "influxdb" is selected as metric DB# MONASCA_METRICS_DB=${MONASCA_METRICS_DB:-vertica}If you also want the Tempest tests to be installed then add `tempest`## Enable Vertica as the Metrics DB using Vagrant Monasca supports using both InfluxDB and Vertica for storing metrics and alarm state history. InfluxDB is enabled by default in the DevStack environment. Vertica is a commercial database from Hewlett Packard Enterprise. A free Community Edition (CE) installer is available for download. To enable Vertica, do the following: 1. Register and download the Vertica Debian installer from `https://my.vertica.com/download/vertica/community-edition/` and put it in your home directory. Unfortunately, there isn't a URL that the DevStack installer can automatically use, so it must be downloaded separately, and put in a location where the installer can find it when it runs. The installer assumes this location is your home directory. When using Vagrant, your home directory will normally be mounted inside the VM as "/vagrant_home". 2. Modify the environment variable `MONASCA_METRICS_DB` in the `local.conf`, `settings` or `Vagrantfile` file from influxdb to vertica as follows: ``` MONASCA_METRICS_DB=${MONASCA_METRICS_DB:-vertica} ``` ## Using PostgreSQL or MySQL Monasca supports using both PostgreSQL and MySQL and so does this devstack plugin. Enable either ```postgresql``` or ```mysql``` to use either of them. To setup environment with MySQL use: ```sh enable_service mysql ``` Alternatively, for PostgreSQL, use: ``` enable_service postgresql ``` ## Using ORM support ORM support can be controlled with ```MONASCA_DATABASE_USE_ORM``` variable. However ORM support is enforced if PostgreSQL is enabled, as the database backend, a.k.a. ```sh enable_service postgresql ``` (c) Copyright 2015-2016 Hewlett Packard Enterprise Development Company LP

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2019-12-09 14:12:58.000000000', 'files': ['ansible/roles/common/templates/conf/input/04-openstack-wsgi.conf.j2', 'ansible/roles/common/templates/conf/input/00-global.conf.j2', 'releasenotes/notes/fix-wsgi-log-collection-c9f347096394df5c.yaml'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/kolla-ansible/commit/a32cddca4974b9ee43c91544be19014a9748c450', 'message': 'Fix fluentd parsing of WSGI logs

WSGI log files use a different input configuration than OpenStack log
files. Currently this depends on log files matching either *-access.log
or *-error.log. Some services use *_access.log or *_error.log, so are
not parsed correctly.

This change modifies the fluentd configuration to accept an underscore
or hyphen for WSGI log file names.

Change-Id: I566d6cac0b6749054fd5422ec8f36f99dacb1db7
Closes-Bug: #1720371
'}]
commit_message:
Fix fluentd parsing of WSGI logs

WSGI log files use a different input configuration than OpenStack log
files. Currently this depends on log files matching either *-access.log
or *-error.log. Some services use *_access.log or *_error.log, so are
not parsed correctly.

This change modifies the fluentd configuration to accept an underscore
or hyphen for WSGI log file names.

Change-Id: I566d6cac0b6749054fd5422ec8f36f99dacb1db7
Closes-Bug: #1720371
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla-ansible refs/changes/16/698016/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: --- fixes: - | Fixes an issue with fluentd parsing of WSGI logs for Aodh, Masakari, Qinling, Vitrage and Zun. See `bug 1720371 <https://bugs.launchpad.net/kolla-ansible/+bug/1720371>`__ for details.

Fix the bug that when user adding a template in dashboard, it always toasts "Unable to validate the Vitrage Templates service.".

commit_message:
Fix monasca-grafana being unbuildable due to old npm

Affected builds on Ubuntu which had:
npm 3.5.2
while the latest was:
npm 6.13.4
And CentOS had:
npm 5.6.0

This patch runs npm update via npm.
Pinned to 6.x.

Additionally, this moves npm packages prefix (root) to
/usr/local to avoid conflicts with native packages.

Change-Id: Ibaacc1cc478b2b2f8196a5da4eea3570d7d310ff
Closes-bug: #1856699
(cherry picked from commit 308e85aa413da84ed107b27fa09a3f0e0a64392f)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla refs/changes/84/699484/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # NOTE(yoctozepto): Update npm to 6.x version to avoid issues with metadata parsing. # NPM installs itself in /usr/local/bin (the default in Ubuntu) which is not in the PATH. # This is forced for all distros to avoid conflicts with native packages. && npm config set prefix /usr/local -g \ && npm install npm@6.x -g \ && /usr/local/bin/npm install \

commit_message:
[ussuri][goal] Drop python 2.7 support

OpenStack is dropping the py2.7 support in ussuri cycle.

specs repo either has py27 job or requirement or tox env.

Ussuri Communtiy-wide goal:
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/selected/ussuri/drop-py27.html

commit_message:
Return version from egg-info and dist-info directly

Rather than using pkg-resources to read the version for a package, which
does a scan of all of the dirs on sys.path and then reading all of the
files in each of the egg-info and dist-info directories found, calculate
the directory from the module import and load the file.

This still will require a scan of the directory the module is in, which
is unavoidable because it's not possible to know the directory of the
metadata without knowing the version, but it should at least cut down
the number of directories scanned and the number of files read that
don't need to be read.

Change-Id: I46e65a1d4bd5cd8cd0b8efd118d13cab7c6e1925

added_lines: def _make_version_packagename(package): return '.'.join([package, '__pbr_version_info']) """Obtain a version from package, pkg_resources or setup-time logic This will try to get the version of the package from a file in the package first, then it will try to get the version of the package from the pkg_resources record associated with the package. If there is no such record falls back to the logic sdist would use. import importlib m = None try: # Try package name as given m = importlib.import_module( _make_version_packagename(self.package)) except ImportError: # Try stripping a leading python- if self.package.startswith('python-'): name = self.package[7:] else: # Try taking out .'s name = self.package.replace('.', '_') # -'s are always wrong name = name.replace('-', '_') try: m = importlib.import_module(_make_version_packagename(name)) except ImportError: pass if m: result_string = m.version else: # Lazy import because pkg_resources is costly to import so defer # until we absolutely need it. import pkg_resources try: requirement = pkg_resources.Requirement.parse(self.package) provider = pkg_resources.get_provider(requirement) result_string = provider.version except pkg_resources.DistributionNotFound: # The most likely cause for this is running tests in a tree # produced from a tarball where the package itself has not been # installed into anything. Revert to setup-time logic. from pbr import packaging result_string = packaging.get_version(self.package)
deleted_lines: """Obtain a version from pkg_resources or setup-time logic if missing. This will try to get the version of the package from the pkg_resources record associated with the package, and if there is no such record falls back to the logic sdist would use. # Lazy import because pkg_resources is costly to import so defer until # we absolutely need it. import pkg_resources try: requirement = pkg_resources.Requirement.parse(self.package) provider = pkg_resources.get_provider(requirement) result_string = provider.version except pkg_resources.DistributionNotFound: # The most likely cause for this is running tests in a tree # produced from a tarball where the package itself has not been # installed into anything. Revert to setup-time logic. from pbr import packaging result_string = packaging.get_version(self.package)

subject: Ensure option groups don't change during logging
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2019-12-18 00:54:29.000000000', 'files': ['oslo_config/cfg.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/oslo.config/commit/bd2ea18a75ae96d02b30d30e9cf131e5941c10ba', 'message': "Ensure option groups don't change during logging

oslo.config allows us to configure groups and options dynamically. This
can cause a race with our logging as we attempt to iterate through
option groups that are changing under our feet. This wouldn't be a huge
issue, since these are just logs are we can always log again, if needed,
but we store groups in a dictionary and Python doesn't like us changing
the size of a dict it's iterating through:

  RuntimeError: dictionary changed size during iteration

Given that we're only reading through this option group and don't need
to worry about a group _disappearing_, the solution is pretty simple:
create a copy of our option group names ahead of time so we don't need
to worry about new ones coming and messing things up.

No tests are included since this is a race and the only way I see to
reproduce this would involve lots of ugly threading.

Change-Id: Id3b28465d645a24f0fcebff2dd68a9bd30e21594

Closes-Bug: #1856312

"}]
commit_message:
Ensure option groups don't change during logging

oslo.config allows us to configure groups and options dynamically. This
can cause a race with our logging as we attempt to iterate through
option groups that are changing under our feet. This wouldn't be a huge
issue, since these are just logs are we can always log again, if needed,
but we store groups in a dictionary and Python doesn't like us changing
the size of a dict it's iterating through:

  RuntimeError: dictionary changed size during iteration

Given that we're only reading through this option group and don't need
to worry about a group _disappearing_, the solution is pretty simple:
create a copy of our option group names ahead of time so we don't need
to worry about new ones coming and messing things up.

No tests are included since this is a race and the only way I see to
reproduce this would involve lots of ugly threading.

Change-Id: Id3b28465d645a24f0fcebff2dd68a9bd30e21594
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <sfinucan@redhat.com>
Closes-Bug: #1856312
(cherry picked from commit e3e2ba55eeeb86a9bc0624bb2592e46583e839e7)

commit_message:
Bump the openstackdocstheme extension to 1.20

Some options are now automatically configured by the version 1.20:
- project
- html_last_updated_fmt
- latex_engine
- latex_elements
- version
- release.

Change-Id: I394f36c791005e87f50f152cc723189dd40e9982

commit_message:
Use topo ordering to correctly sort changelog entries

Call git log with --topo-order so that old changes merged in after a
tagged release do not appear in the changelog entries for that release.

Change-Id: I9ea5ef4d1d7c3ec4d57d17a40c67971c30ec6105

commit_message:
Add support for a docs extra aligned with RTD locations

readthedocs.org looks for docs/requirements.txt and if found will
install those files before building docs. We currently lump all of our
doc requirements in with test requirements in OpenStack, which makes it
harder to keep clear why a particular requirement is desired.

Similar to parsing and adding test-requirements.txt to the test extra,
add an extra called 'docs' and put the contents of doc/requirements.txt
in it. This should allow us to have repos that are more generally
compatible with the wider ecosystem, and to stop installing
documentation generation packages for unittests if we don't otherwise
need to.

Change-Id: Ibc46e0132c233b6f7f2e9dfc6a6f8e2e2ed4643c

commit_message:
Fix failure of updating old version object

Update of old version object fails when
object doesn't have a attribute which
has been added newly in latest version.

We should consider this case by
accepting a NotImplementedError.

Closes-Bug: #1615922
Change-Id: I2c9773ba06aa5d7af0c4c74e3090e219843ed3e1

commit_message:
Change python3.5 job to python3.7 job on Stein+

python3.5 was the only supported python3 version on Xenial, now that we have
Bionic Beaver nodes that support python3.7, lets switch to testing with
python3.7 in addition with python3.6 in Stein and beyond.
See ML discussion here [1] for context.

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2018-October/135632.html

Change-Id: If13bc1027ab9688815ed011380e61ef0f5c3c3a7
Signed-off-by: Charles Short <chucks@redhat.com>
