commit_message:
Add eventlet-aware Timer object to eventletutils

This Timer object is a copy of the threading.Timer implementation,
except it uses the eventlet-aware Event implementation from
eventletutils.  This avoids busy-waiting on Events that occurs when
using the threading implementation with eventlet.

Change-Id: Ib727fb3fd67864a7334097e5bfeed694b39248ce
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo.utils refs/changes/55/558555/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: class _Timer(threading.Thread): """A class that provides the threading Timer API but uses the eventlet Event implementation when eventlet is used. """ def __init__(self, interval, function, args=[], kwargs={}): threading.Thread.__init__(self) self.interval = interval self.function = function self.args = args self.kwargs = kwargs self.finished = Event() def cancel(self): """Stop the timer if it hasn't finished yet""" self.finished.set() def run(self): self.finished.wait(self.interval) if not self.finished.is_set(): self.function(*self.args, **self.kwargs) self.finished.set() def Timer(*args, **kwargs): if is_monkey_patched("thread"): return _Timer(*args, **kwargs) else: return threading.Timer(*args, **kwargs)

subject: Check for valid uuid length
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-08-29 12:25:50.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/oslo.utils/commit/7b31cae8f07f839a1f92efaca311d65056dd0d62', 'message': 'Check for valid uuid length

A valid uuid consists of 32 characters and 4 -.
As per current behavior if user passes more -
in uuid (for example, aaaa---aaaa-aaaa----aaaa-aaaa---aaaa-aaaa-aaaa)
then is_uuit_like function treats it is valid uuid and returns True
because while checking it is replacing all - with empty string and
checking for 32 characters only. This is causing db error where in
database table uuid value is set to 36 but actual value of uuid is
greater than that.

To resolve this issue I have added a new method name as
"format_canonical_uuid" in the uuidutils module which will verify
the fixed number of hyphens in the uuid and convert it in a valid
format and returns otherwise treat it as invalid uuid and raise
ValueError with appropriate error message.

Related-Bug: #1680130

commit_message:
Check for valid uuid length

A valid uuid consists of 32 characters and 4 -(hyphens).
As per current behavior if user passes more -(hyphens)
in uuid (for example, aaaa---aaaa-aaaa----aaaa-aaaa---aaaa-aaaa-aaaa)
then is_uuit_like function treats it as valid uuid and returns True
because while checking it is replacing all - with empty string and
checking for 32 characters only. This is causing db error where in
database table uuid value is set to 36 but actual value of uuid is
greater than that.

To resolve this issue I have added a new method name as
"format_canonical_uuid" in the uuidutils module which will verify
the fixed number of hyphens in the uuid and convert it in a valid
format and returns otherwise treat it as invalid uuid and raise
ValueError with appropriate error message.

Related-Bug: #1680130
Change-Id: Ic2e9aabc644ef386813a03f1d7d570e86f8705af
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo.utils refs/changes/86/498786/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def format_canonical_uuid(val): """Returns valid formatted UUID in canonical form, For example - "11111111-2222-3333-4444-555555555555". :param val: uuid in string format :returns: string :raises: ValueError """ error_msg = "Invalid value: %s" try: if val.count('-') not in (0, 4): raise ValueError(error_msg % val) return str(uuid.UUID(val)) except (TypeError, AttributeError, ValueError): raise ValueError(error_msg % val)

commit_message:
Allow 'forever_retry_uncaught_exceptions' to take a custom logger

Sometimes it is more appropriate to use a projects own logger
instead of the default root logger, so make such a thing possible
to do.

This also removes the usage of mox from the retry exception
testing and replaces it with mock instead (because the tests
were affected and just removing old & busted mox is easier at
this point).

Change-Id: Ia0f4adbc5f62be0a6a35a4c698b2779581171ca7

commit_message:
Add a safe_format to strutils

Formatting strings has the potential to be unsafe because it
allows access to builtins such as __class__, __init__, as indicated
in [1].

It's more dangerous when the format is used with a parameter that
is a Python object.

[1]: http://lucumr.pocoo.org/2016/12/29/careful-with-str-format/

Change-Id: I1300bac4276facf2fe16af1b7028f56bdc9b482f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo.utils refs/changes/36/437136/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from collections import Mappingfrom string import Formatter# This is a necessary API but it's undocumented and moved around # between Python releases try: from _string import formatter_field_name_split except ImportError: formatter_field_name_split = lambda x: x._formatter_field_name_split() class MagicFormatMapping(Mapping): """This class implements a dummy wrapper to fix a bug in the Python standard library for string formatting. See http://bugs.python.org/issue13598 for information about why this is necessary. """ def __init__(self, args, kwargs): self._args = args self._kwargs = kwargs self._last_index = 0 def __getitem__(self, key): if key == '': idx = self._last_index self._last_index += 1 try: return self._args[idx] except LookupError: pass key = str(idx) return self._kwargs[key] def __iter__(self): return iter(self._kwargs) def __len__(self): return len(self._kwargs) class SafeFormatter(Formatter): def get_field(self, field_name, args, kwargs): first, rest = formatter_field_name_split(field_name) obj = self.get_value(first, args, kwargs) for is_attr, i in rest: if is_attr: obj = self._safe_getattr(obj, i) else: obj = obj[i] return obj, first def _safe_getattr(self, obj, attr): # Expand the logic here. For instance on 2.x you will also need # to disallow func_globals, on 3.x you will also need to hide # things like cr_frame and others. So ideally have a list of # objects that are entirely unsafe to access. if attr[:1] == '_': raise AttributeError(attr) return getattr(obj, attr) def safe_format(_string, *args, **kwargs): """Safely format a string and throws an AttribError if calls to builtins are used. For example: {0.__class__} :param _string: string to format :param args: arguments :param kwargs: keyword arguments .. versionadded:: 3.23 """ formatter = SafeFormatter() kwargs = MagicFormatMapping(args, kwargs) return formatter.vformat(_string, args, kwargs)

commit_message:
Run rootwrap with lower fd ulimit by default

On Python 2.x, a subprocess.Popen() with close_fds=True will
fork and then close filedescriptors range(3..os.sysconf("SC_OPEN_MAX")),
which thanks to Kernel PTI (Kaiser patches) is significantly slower
in 2018 when the range is very large. With a soft limit of 1048576,
benchmark.py reports an overhead of ~ 400ms without this patch and 2ms
with the patch applied. This patch adds a configuration option and
leaves it disabled for the stable/* backports to not change default
behavior.

Also includes Ben Nemec's release note entry, adjusted for the stable
backport. This is Ib29e96307caa39c21936f216d9aed7907e7a7331 for master.

Also includes I2391315f77718a3c9eb9fc8c03a6882237f33548 from master.

Also includes I3b481ddd14ae2b948270d715aad157cf3996def7 from master.

(cherry picked from commit c0a86998203315858721a7b2c8ab75fbf5cd51d9)
(cherry picked from commit 8f148f5e9e786d8a3922b0d5ae29bc54b8e8e1e9)
(cherry picked from commit 5259c08c09eb3aeab64af928cddf84bc213594d3)

Closes-Bug: 1796267
Closes-Bug: #1804639
Change-Id: Idd98c183eca3e2df8648fc0f37d27fe9cc6d0563
(cherry picked from commit c338f2c5c79abd44be5da495ae980fe7aefe194d)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo.rootwrap refs/changes/88/613388/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import resourcefrom oslo_rootwrap import subprocessfrom six import moves # When use close_fds=True on Python 2.x, we spend significant time # in closing fds up to current soft ulimit, which could be large. # Lower our ulimit to a reasonable value to regain performance. fd_limits = resource.getrlimit(resource.RLIMIT_NOFILE) sensible_fd_limit = min(config.rlimit_nofile, fd_limits[0]) if (fd_limits[0] > sensible_fd_limit): # Unfortunately this inherits to our children, so allow them to # re-raise by passing through the hard limit unmodified resource.setrlimit( resource.RLIMIT_NOFILE, (sensible_fd_limit, fd_limits[1])) # This is set on import to the hard ulimit. if its defined we # already have imported it, so we need to update it to the new limit if (hasattr(subprocess, 'MAXFD') and subprocess.MAXFD > sensible_fd_limit): subprocess.MAXFD = sensible_fd_limit

commit_message:
Run rootwrap with lower fd ulimit by default

On Python 2.x, a subprocess.Popen() with close_fds=True will
fork and then close filedescriptors range(3..os.sysconf("SC_OPEN_MAX")),
which thanks to Kernel PTI (Kaiser patches) is significantly slower
in 2018 when the range is very large. With a soft limit of 1048576,
benchmark.py reports an overhead of ~ 400ms without this patch and 2ms
with the patch applied. This patch adds a configuration option and
leaves it disabled for the stable/* backports to not change default
behavior.

Also includes Ben Nemec's release note entry, adjusted for the stable
backport. This is Ib29e96307caa39c21936f216d9aed7907e7a7331 for master.

Also includes I2391315f77718a3c9eb9fc8c03a6882237f33548 from master.

Also includes I3b481ddd14ae2b948270d715aad157cf3996def7 from master.

(cherry picked from commit c0a86998203315858721a7b2c8ab75fbf5cd51d9)
(cherry picked from commit 8f148f5e9e786d8a3922b0d5ae29bc54b8e8e1e9)
(cherry picked from commit 5259c08c09eb3aeab64af928cddf84bc213594d3)

added_lines: import resourcefrom oslo_rootwrap import subprocessfrom six import moves # When use close_fds=True on Python 2.x, we spend significant time # in closing fds up to current soft ulimit, which could be large. # Lower our ulimit to a reasonable value to regain performance. fd_limits = resource.getrlimit(resource.RLIMIT_NOFILE) sensible_fd_limit = min(config.rlimit_nofile, fd_limits[0]) if (fd_limits[0] > sensible_fd_limit): # Unfortunately this inherits to our children, so allow them to # re-raise by passing through the hard limit unmodified resource.setrlimit( resource.RLIMIT_NOFILE, (sensible_fd_limit, fd_limits[1])) # This is set on import to the hard ulimit. if its defined we # already have imported it, so we need to update it to the new limit if (hasattr(subprocess, 'MAXFD') and subprocess.MAXFD > sensible_fd_limit): subprocess.MAXFD = sensible_fd_limit

added_lines: def check_match_args(self, userargs): if not userargs or userargs[0] != "kill": return None return None return None return None return args def match(self, userargs): args = self.check_match_args(userargs) if not args: return Falseclass KillRegexpFilter(KillFilter): def match(self, userargs): args = self.check_match_args(userargs) if not args: return False # Don't allow empty string as a pattern if self.args[0] == "": return False try: with open("/proc/%d/cmdline" % int(args[1])) as f: cmdline = f.read().replace("\0", " ").rstrip() except (ValueError, EnvironmentError): # Incorrect PID return False if re.search(self.args[0], cmdline): return True return False

commit_message:
Avoid importing eventlet.patcher from cmd.py

By importing eventlet.patcher from the main module initialisation,
we're importing a large part of code unnecessarily for the short-lived
rootwrap client case. With the existing code this is:

  $ time sudo /usr/bin/cinder-rootwrap /etc/cinder/rootwrap.conf id
  uid=0(root) gid=0(root) groups=0(root)

  real    0m4,067s
  user    0m0,821s
  sys     0m0,185s

This is because it imports various DNS and crypto libraries (which
in return do setup a lot of things like gather entropy and the like).
With this patch this reduces to:

  $ time sudo /usr/bin/cinder-rootwrap /etc/cinder/rootwrap.conf id
  uid=0(root) gid=0(root) groups=0(root)

  real    0m1,279s
  user    0m0,192s
  sys     0m0,060s

which is, depending on which metrics you're looking at, up to 4 times
faster.

Change-Id: If098738924e78e76d1c19a329dd8db509022c922

commit_message:
Detach from the parent using fork and exit

Today, every rootwrap daemon process is associated with its
parent sudo command, which serves no purpose.
In traditional unix programming, daemon processes call daemon(3)
to detach from their parents. Follow the tradition to kill those
useless sudo processes.

Change-Id: If824ccfa772404a40727b8dfd10c78da17730569

commit_message:
Expose caps values/names as int enum (WIP)

This avoids some of the lookup needed via globals()
and such to create a name and value mapping and makes
it a little easier to document the various caps.

Change-Id: I0325fc3229adfe851c4692e07d61433da3961c46

added_lines: import enum class Capabilities(enum.IntEnum): """Currently used sys capabilities (expand as needed).""" CAP_CHOWN = 0 CAP_DAC_OVERRIDE = 1 CAP_FOWNER = 3 CAP_KILL = 5 CAP_SETPCAP = 8 CAP_NET_BIND_SERVICE = 10 CAP_NET_BROADCAST = 11 CAP_NET_ADMIN = 12 CAP_NET_RAW = 13 CAP_SYS_ADMIN = 21 # Expose them as various useful module level dicts and attrs. commit_message:
[PoC] Add new kind of check called 'tags'

Add new check kind for matching tag. Auth token from Keystone now
exposes 'project_tags' and several sub components related to the
attribute now accept new attribute.

Admin can control this kind of check using tag based policy per
project. Possible use cases are look like

- "tags:production"
- "tags:develop"
- "tags:staging and tags:test"
- "tags:%(tags)s"

Tag is orginally list attribute so that this kind of check match
two specified lists are overlapped. If there were any matched tagging
from two lists, check returns True.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/654301
Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/654309
Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/654307
Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/654305

Change-Id: I7f450344d93424dc6c9379ae905e87f8f0dac09b
Closes-bug: #1807697
Closes-bug: #1825336
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo.policy refs/changes/21/654321/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: @register('tags') class TagCheck(Check): """Check whether the project tag list in the ``creds`` dict overlaps.""" def __call__(self, target, creds, enforcer, current_rule=None): try: match = self.match % target tags = creds['project_tags'] except KeyError: return False try: match = ast.literal_eval(match) except ValueError: pass if not isinstance(match, list): match = [match] if any([tag for tag in tags if tag in match]): return True return False

commit_message:
Create OPA check

This creates a simple check that uses Open Policy Agent to evaluate
policy.

The recommended deployment is to use a system daemon or a sidecar
container, so the code is pretty simple to address that. However, it is
possible to use TLS for authentication/authorization, thus the option to
use TLS is available here.

Change-Id: Idd909c515a327bf20bb098b7ea708d7a2b549f16
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo.policy refs/changes/24/614224/6 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # -*- coding: utf-8 -*- # # Copyright (c) 2018 OpenStack Foundation. # All Rights Reserved. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import contextlib import copy import os from oslo_policy import _checks from oslo_policy._i18n import _ import requests class OPACheck(_checks.Check): """Check ``opa:`` rules by calling to an Open Policy Agent instance. This implementation simply verifies that the response is exactly ``{"result": True}``. """ def __call__(self, target, creds, enforcer, current_rule=None): url = self.match request_kwargs = {} if url.startswith("https:"): cert_file = enforcer.conf.oslo_policy.opa_ssl_client_crt_file key_file = enforcer.conf.oslo_policy.opa_ssl_client_key_file ca_crt_file = enforcer.conf.oslo_policy.opa_ssl_ca_crt_file verify_server = enforcer.conf.oslo_policy.opa_ssl_verify_server_crt if cert_file: if not os.path.exists(cert_file): raise RuntimeError( _("Unable to find ssl cert_file : %s") % cert_file) if not os.access(cert_file, os.R_OK): raise RuntimeError( _("Unable to access ssl cert_file : %s") % cert_file) if key_file: if not os.path.exists(key_file): raise RuntimeError( _("Unable to find ssl key_file : %s") % key_file) if not os.access(key_file, os.R_OK): raise RuntimeError( _("Unable to access ssl key_file : %s") % key_file) cert = (cert_file, key_file) if verify_server and ca_crt_file: if not os.path.exists(ca_crt_file): raise RuntimeError( _("Unable to find ca cert_file : %s") % ca_crt_file) verify_server = ca_crt_file request_kwargs = { "cert": cert, "verify": verify_server } elif not url.startswith("http:"): raise RuntimeError("The URL %s is not valid" % url) json = self._construct_payload(creds, current_rule, enforcer, target) with contextlib.closing( requests.post(url, json=json, **request_kwargs) ) as resp: data = resp.json() try: return data['result'] is True except (ValueError, KeyError): return False @staticmethod def _construct_payload(creds, current_rule, enforcer, target): # Convert instances of object() in target temporarily to # empty dict to avoid circular reference detection # errors in jsonutils.dumps(). temp_target = copy.deepcopy(target) for key in target.keys(): element = target.get(key) if type(element) is object: temp_target[key] = {} return { 'input': { 'rule': current_rule, 'target': temp_target, 'credentials': creds } }

commit_message:
Do not bind python2 specific directory into container

Use more generic path to place storlets python codes, so that
we can use the same path for python2 and python3.

Change-Id: Ia4ee0790ea58a42173f58bed2f59249c0b7edfd9

added_lines: # Install python library to be mouted by containers SRC=storlets DST=/usr/local/lib/storlets/python mkdir -p $DST chmod 755 $DST cp -r $SRC $DST

commit_message:
Software RAID: Identify the root fs via its UUID from image metadata

In order to install the bootloader on instances with software RAID,
the IPA needs to chroot into the deployed image's root fs. Currently,
the IPA assumes the first partition to contain the root fs, so this
breaks with images where this is not the case. The proposed change
extracts the root fs UUID from the image's metadata instead and
passes it to the IPA (in the same way this is done for partition
images). It keeps the current behaviour to send the UUID extracted
from the driver internal info in case the metadata is not set on
the image. For the time being, the IPA completely ignores the UUID
passed anyway, so to make this fully work the IPA will also need
to be patched.

Change-Id: I69bd53aa24b7b10384dc1399a0acaa21d38d6bd9
Story: #2006649
Task: #37081
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic refs/changes/80/686580/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from ironic.common import image_service # For software RAID try to get the UUID of the root fs from the # image's metadata (via Glance). Fall back to the driver internal # info in case it is not available (e.g. not set or there's no Glance). if software_raid: image_source = node.instance_info.get('image_source') try: context = task.context context.is_admin = True glance = image_service.GlanceImageService( context=context) image_info = glance.show(image_source) image_properties = image_info.get('properties') root_uuid = image_properties['rootfs_uuid'] LOG.debug('Got rootfs_uuid from Glance: %s', root_uuid) except Exception as e: LOG.warning('Could not get \'rootfs_uuid\' property for ' 'image %(image)s from Glance: %(error)s.', {'image': image_source, 'error': e}) root_uuid = internal_info.get('root_uuid_or_disk_id') LOG.debug('Got rootfs_uuid from driver internal info: ' ' %s', root_uuid)

commit_message:
[WIP] Add OpenTracing instrumentation

This patch switches instrumentation from osprofiler to
opentracing to allow all consumers of keystoneauth library
to become compatible with OpenTracing (ex. CNCF Jaeger).

Refs:
 [1] Mail thread:
     http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-April/005006.html
 [2] All patches in series:
     https://review.openstack.org/#/q/status:open+topic:opentracing

Change-Id: I5c36efa74a92cf38731d21abfecd1b0a19974cce
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystoneauth refs/changes/80/652080/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import opentracing from opentracing.ext import tags as ext_tags from opentracing.propagation import Format # Start OpenTracing span and inject it into headers # todo: with osprofiler the start notification is sent immediately, # thus all tags need to be specified in start() call, not after tags = { ext_tags.SPAN_KIND: ext_tags.SPAN_KIND_RPC_CLIENT, ext_tags.HTTP_METHOD: method, ext_tags.HTTP_URL: url, } scope = opentracing.tracer.start_active_span('keystoneauth1', tags=tags) span = scope.span opentracing.tracer.inject(span, Format.HTTP_HEADERS, kwargs['headers']) # update and close OpenTracing span span.set_tag(ext_tags.HTTP_STATUS_CODE, resp.status_code) scope.close()

This adds optional instrumentation into the client to allow
users collect the whole trace information.

 [2] All patches in series:

added_lines: import osopentracing = importutils.try_import("opentracing") osprofiler_initializer = importutils.try_import("osprofiler.initializer") connection_string = os.getenv('OSPROFILER_CONNECTION_STRING') # init tracer osprofiler_initializer.init_tracer( service='openstack-cli', connection_string=connection_string, hmac_keys=[self.options.profile]) # start the trace scope = opentracing.tracer.start_active_span('shell') scope.span.log_kv({'event': 'enter'}) # osprofiler_profiler.init(self.options.profile) span = opentracing.tracer.active_span span.log_kv({'event': 'exit'}) span.finish() # todo: that's for Jaeger only import time time.sleep(2) opentracing.tracer.close()
deleted_lines: osprofiler_profiler.init(self.options.profile) profiler = osprofiler_profiler.get() trace_id = profiler.get_base_id() # Short ID for OpenTracing-based driver (64-bit id) short_id = profiler.get_shorten_id(trace_id) # NOTE(dbelova): let's use warning log level to see these messages # printed. In fact we can define custom log level here with value # bigger than most big default one (CRITICAL) or something like # that (PROFILE = 60 for instance), but not sure we need it here. self.log.warning("Trace ID: %s" % trace_id) self.log.warning("Short trace ID " "for OpenTracing-based drivers: %s" % short_id) self.log.warning("Display trace data with command:\n" "osprofiler trace show --html %s " % trace_id)

commit_message:
[WIP] Make osprofiler OpenTracing-compatible

Changes:
 * Switch to OpenTracing instrumentation in web middleware, sqlalchemy
   handlers and trace decorator
 * Add OpenTracing-compatible tracer that reports spans in existing \
   osprofiler format

     http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-April/005006.html

deleted_lines: info = {"db": { "statement": statement, "params": params} } profiler.start(name, info=info) if not hide_result: # Add SQL result to trace info in *-stop phase info = { "db": { "result": str(cursor._rows) } } profiler.stop(info=info) else: profiler.stop()

commit_message:
Update TOX/UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for feature/nats-driver

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as feature/nats-driver branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

commit_message:
Remove some description from oslo policy

A lot of the content about how rules work and the rule syntax from
https://docs.openstack.org/oslo.policy/latest/reference/api/oslo_policy.policy.html
should move somewhere into the user section of that guide. That
probably means moving it out of the source code and into the doc tree.

bug-list https://bugs.launchpad.net/oslo.policy/+bug/1713055

Change-Id: I3e8a3f7cf3b1f5aca130b2e7866c47731061eb2c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo.policy refs/changes/83/576683/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
deleted_lines: """ Common Policy Engine Implementation Policies are expressed as a target and an associated rule:: "<target>": <rule> The `target` is specific to the service that is conducting policy enforcement. Typically, the target refers to an API call. For the `<rule>` part, see `Policy Rule Expressions`. Policy Rule Expressions ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ Policy rules can be expressed in one of two forms: a string written in the new policy language or a list of lists. The string format is preferred since it's easier for most people to understand. In the policy language, each check is specified as a simple "a:b" pair that is matched to the correct class to perform that check: +--------------------------------+------------------------------------------+ | TYPE | SYNTAX | +================================+==========================================+ |User's Role | role:admin | +--------------------------------+------------------------------------------+ |Rules already defined on policy | rule:admin_required | +--------------------------------+------------------------------------------+ |Against URLs¹ | http://my-url.org/check | +--------------------------------+------------------------------------------+ |User attributes² | project_id:%(target.project.id)s | +--------------------------------+------------------------------------------+ |Strings | - <variable>:'xpto2035abc' | | | - 'myproject':<variable> | +--------------------------------+------------------------------------------+ | | - project_id:xpto2035abc | |Literals | - domain_id:20 | | | - True:%(user.enabled)s | +--------------------------------+------------------------------------------+ ¹URL checking must return ``True`` to be valid ²User attributes (obtained through the token): user_id, domain_id or project_id Conjunction operators ``and`` and ``or`` are available, allowing for more expressiveness in crafting policies. For example:: "role:admin or (project_id:%(project_id)s and role:projectadmin)" The policy language also has the ``not`` operator, allowing a richer policy rule:: "project_id:%(project_id)s and not role:dunce" Operator precedence is below: +------------+-------------+-------------+ | PRECEDENCE | TYPE | EXPRESSION | +============+=============+=============+ | 4 | Grouping | (...) | +------------+-------------+-------------+ | 3 | Logical NOT | not ... | +------------+-------------+-------------+ | 2 | Logical AND | ... and ... | +------------+-------------+-------------+ | 1 | Logical OR | ... or ... | +------------+-------------+-------------+ Operator with larger precedence number precedes others with smaller numbers. In the list-of-lists representation, each check inside the innermost list is combined as with an "and" conjunction -- for that check to pass, all the specified checks must pass. These innermost lists are then combined as with an "or" conjunction. As an example, take the following rule, expressed in the list-of-lists representation:: [["role:admin"], ["project_id:%(project_id)s", "role:projectadmin"]] Finally, two special policy checks should be mentioned; the policy check "@" will always accept an access, and the policy check "!" will always reject an access. (Note that if a rule is either the empty list (``[]``) or the empty string (``""``), this is equivalent to the "@" policy check.) Of these, the "!" policy check is probably the most useful, as it allows particular rules to be explicitly disabled. Generic Checks ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ A `generic` check is used to perform matching against attributes that are sent along with the API calls. These attributes can be used by the policy engine (on the right side of the expression), by using the following syntax:: <some_attribute>:%(user.id)s The value on the right-hand side is either a string or resolves to a string using regular Python string substitution. The available attributes and values are dependent on the program that is using the common policy engine. All of these attributes (related to users, API calls, and context) can be checked against each other or against constants. It is important to note that these attributes are specific to the service that is conducting policy enforcement. Generic checks can be used to perform policy checks on the following user attributes obtained through a token: - user_id - domain_id or project_id (depending on the token scope) - list of roles held for the given token scope .. note:: Some resources which are exposed by the API do not support policy enforcement by user_id, and only support policy enforcement by project_id. Some global resources do not support policy enforcement by combination of user_id and project_id. For example, a check on the user_id would be defined as:: user_id:<some_value> Together with the previously shown example, a complete generic check would be:: user_id:%(user.id)s It is also possible to perform checks against other attributes that represent the credentials. This is done by adding additional values to the ``creds`` dict that is passed to the :meth:`~oslo_policy.policy.Enforcer.enforce` method. Special Checks ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ Special checks allow for more flexibility than is possible using generic checks. The built-in special check types are ``role``, ``rule``, and ``http`` checks. Role Check ^^^^^^^^^^ A ``role`` check is used to check if a specific role is present in the supplied credentials. A role check is expressed as:: "role:<role_name>" Rule Check ^^^^^^^^^^ A :class:`rule check <oslo_policy.policy.RuleCheck>` is used to reference another defined rule by its name. This allows for common checks to be defined once as a reusable rule, which is then referenced within other rules. It also allows one to define a set of checks as a more descriptive name to aid in readability of policy. A rule check is expressed as:: "rule:<rule_name>" The following example shows a role check that is defined as a rule, which is then used via a rule check:: "admin_required": "role:admin" "<target>": "rule:admin_required" HTTP Check ^^^^^^^^^^ An ``http`` check is used to make an HTTP request to a remote server to determine the results of the check. The target and credentials are passed to the remote server for evaluation. The action is authorized if the remote server returns a response of ``True``. An http check is expressed as:: "http:<target URI>" It is expected that the target URI contains a string formatting keyword, where the keyword is a key from the target dictionary. An example of an http check where the `name` key from the target is used to construct the URL is would be defined as:: "http://server.test/%(name)s" Registering New Special Checks ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^ It is also possible for additional special check types to be registered using the :func:`~oslo_policy.policy.register` function. The following classes can be used as parents for custom special check types: * :class:`~oslo_policy.policy.AndCheck` * :class:`~oslo_policy.policy.NotCheck` * :class:`~oslo_policy.policy.OrCheck` * :class:`~oslo_policy.policy.RuleCheck` Default Rule ~~~~~~~~~~~~ A default rule can be defined, which will be enforced when a rule does not exist for the target that is being checked. By default, the rule associated with the rule name of ``default`` will be used as the default rule. It is possible to use a different rule name as the default rule by setting the ``policy_default_rule`` configuration setting to the desired rule name. """

commit_message:
Remove oslo_middleware.http_proxy_to_wsgi marked in ssl

HTTP proxy to WSGI termination middleware was no longer needed in
SSLMiddleware in new release, and it was deprecated for removal.

Change-Id: If888487d184ddc3eedb8612829f0fc6a71ccbcd4
Closes-Bug: #1715096

commit_message:
Change python3.5 job to python3.7 job on Stein+

python3.5 was the only supported python3 version on Xenial, now that we have
Bionic Beaver nodes that support python3.7, lets switch to testing with
python3.7 in addition with python3.6 in Stein and beyond.
See ML discussion here [1] for context.

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2018-October/135632.html

Change-Id: Idcd8fd73efddf9ef82dcb55ebbc20c8f08bcfb6d
Signed-off-by: Charles Short <chucks@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Move all loggers under 'oslo.' package namespace

Replace all the non-namespaced prefixs 'oslo_' of loggers names with 'oslo.'
to maintain backward compatibility with log level configurations in production
For example: oslo=WARN or oslo.messaging=INFO

You can find the discussion about it here:
(see Doug Hellmann comments)
  - https://review.openstack.org/#/c/303581/

Change-Id: I15d1216a2554da950d09624dc98bcc4dd0be294f

subject: Retry to declare a queue after internal error
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2019-04-23 07:49:37.000000000', 'files': ['oslo_messaging/_drivers/impl_rabbit.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/oslo.messaging/commit/0297c5f0ccfa411aded1a1cb3559de90aa276dd3', 'message': "Retry to declare a queue after internal error

Without this commit, the client can lose the messages, because the
client does not handler the 'AMQP internal error 541',
read here [2] for details.
The fix retries to create the queue after a delay.
When the virtual-host is ready the declare does not fail.
This is a rare condiction, please read the bug [1] for details.

Closes-Bug: #1822778

[1] https://bugs.launchpad.net/oslo.messaging/+bug/1822778
[2] https://www.rabbitmq.com/amqp-0-9-1-reference.html

Change-Id: I7ab1f9d21ebb807285bf1422bc14cc6e07dcd32a
(cherry picked from commit 4d2787227b00b973973554f7387e621d2664c0d8)
"}]
commit_message:
Retry to declare a queue after internal error

Without this commit, the client can lose the messages, because the
client does not handler the 'AMQP internal error 541',
read here [2] for details.
The fix retries to create the queue after a delay.
When the virtual-host is ready the declare does not fail.
This is a rare condiction, please read the bug [1] for details.

Closes-Bug: #1822778

[1] https://bugs.launchpad.net/oslo.messaging/+bug/1822778
[2] https://www.rabbitmq.com/amqp-0-9-1-reference.html

Change-Id: I7ab1f9d21ebb807285bf1422bc14cc6e07dcd32a
(cherry picked from commit 4d2787227b00b973973554f7387e621d2664c0d8)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo.messaging refs/changes/17/654817/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: except kombu.exceptions.ConnectionError as exc: # NOTE(gsantomaggio): This exception happens when the # connection is established,but it fails to create the queue. # Add some delay to avoid too many requests to the server. # See: https://bugs.launchpad.net/oslo.messaging/+bug/1822778 # for details. if exc.code == 541: interval = 2 info = {'sleep_time': interval, 'queue': self.queue_name, 'err_str': exc } LOG.error(_LE('Internal amqp error (541) ' 'during queue declare,' 'retrying in %(sleep_time)s seconds. ' 'Queue: [%(queue)s], ' 'error message: [%(err_str)s]'), info) time.sleep(interval) self.queue.declare() else: raise

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2018-12-06 16:40:46.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/oslo.messaging/commit/6e501662fdd9d54e533791e974f523d9093a62c4', 'message': 'RFC: Add osprofiler tracing for RPC calls

This proposed patch will integrate osprofiling into the RPC library to
allow projects to trace flows across RPC calls.

code to support tracing across RPC calls.  This patch is based on
their work (IIUC this patch will not conflict with their

commit_message:
RFC: Add osprofiler tracing for RPC calls

This proposed patch will integrate osprofiling into the RPC library to
allow projects to trace flows across RPC calls.

Projects like Nova and Neutron have taken steps to instrument their
code to support tracing across RPC calls.  This patch is based on
their work (IIUC this patch will not conflict with their
implementation - TBD if true)

Projects that want to trace across RPC calls will need to add
tracepoints as necessary to client code making RPC calls and wrap the
endpoint classes on the server properly - see the additional unit test
as an example.

Change-Id: I0bcf7ec932d0d9282b3063dccb7107e69e62eb21
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo.messaging refs/changes/54/623254/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from oslo_utils import importutils profiler = importutils.try_import("osprofiler.profiler") # send profiler state to the server for tracing the RPC call if profiler: prof = profiler.get() if prof: msg['osprofiler'] = { 'hmac_key': prof.hmac_key, 'base_id': prof.get_base_id(), 'parent_id': prof.get_id() }

commit_message:
Tell the multinode subnode and grenade to use /opt

It was changed on the primary node, but not the subnode
of the standard mutlinode job, and not updated on our
grenade job.

Changes subnode and grenade configuration to use it.

Change-Id: I8f67e3e3423e72944d22d65b788af5792ee900f9

commit_message:
WIP Queue messages on consumer rather than an external queue

This is a rough PoC on how this might be achieved. This is motivated by
a few goals:

1. It would be nice to have RPC dispatch prioritize different methods.

2. It would be nice to queue messages in a place that a service can
introspect easily. RabbitMQ appears to be the commonly used queue at the
moment but it's not easy to query it in order to determine if some RPC
call is in the queue vs it was consumed and dropped.

Change-Id: If669f7c5578bbc4e55379af4c3b901ee98eb0bec
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo.messaging refs/changes/36/294236/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import collections import functools class LocalMessageQueue(object): def __init__(self, endpoint): self.endpoint = endpoint self.executor = rpc_dispatcher.PriorityGreenThreadPoolExecutor() def __getattr__(self, attr): endpoint_attr = getattr(self.endpoint, attr) if attr == 'target': # Special case this until a better distinction found return endpoint_attr if isinstance(endpoint_attr, collections.Callable): return functools.partial(self._enqueue, attr) return endpoint_attr def _enqueue(self, method_name, reply_callback, serializer, ctxt, *args, **kwargs): method = getattr(self.endpoint, method_name) future_job = self.executor.submit(method, ctxt, *args, **kwargs) def job_complete(fut): reply_callback(serializer.serialize_entity(ctxt, fut.result())) future_job.add_done_callback(job_complete) queued_endpoints = [LocalMessageQueue(endpoint) for endpoint in endpoints] dispatcher = rpc_dispatcher.RPCDispatcherWithDeferredReply(target, queued_endpoints, serializer)

commit_message:
Fix socket getting in the set_transport_socket_timeout()

The set_transport_socket_timeout() use self.channel to obtain the socket,
but if during reconnection the set_transport_socket_timeout was called
before _set_current_channel(new_channel) it leads to the:

[-] Failed to get socket attribute: 'NoneType' object has no attribute 'sock' set_transport_socket_timeout

because self.channel was closed at this moment.

So, to fix it just use self.connection.connection.sock instead of
self.channel.*

Change-Id: I0dae7ee96ce052dec4c71c06b975966596cae011
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo.messaging refs/changes/89/357189/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: self.set_transport_socket_timeout() sock = self.connection.connection.sock

commit_message:
Fix tox environments

Work items:

* Removed the globale-requirements constraint. Since python-cloudkittyclient
  is now part of the global requirements, the upstream requirements
  file can't be used anymore.

* Add cliff to docs requirements.

* Change cloudkittyclient namespace names: Having a dot in a namespace
  name causes the "autoprogram-cliff" to use the "application mode".

Change-Id: I8020d816b3397550fbcbd42cc14a9861bca7ae80
